Table of Contents








Scope of this document

This document describes the TCPWave IPAMs architecture, components, GUI administration, security and tuning details. It also describes the basic IPAM principles and gives guidance to operate the TCPWave IPAM.

Who should read this guide?

This book is intended for a technical audience. The audience may include network planners, IPAM administrators, and DNS and DHCP administrators. Readers of this book should have some background in DNS and DHCP as well as general network concepts. This guide helps while planning or during installation of the IPAM for a network.

Network Management

DNS Management

DNS Appliances

DNS stands for Domain Name System. It provides resolution to a web URL. It converts web URL into an IP address. TCPWave IPAM contains 5 types of appliances.

They are: ISC BIND Authoritative, ISC BIND Cache, NSD Authoritative, UNBOUND Cache, DNS Proxy appliance.

TCPWave DNS Appliances

Adding DNS Appliance

To add a DNS Appliance in the IPAM, go to DNS Appliances page by clicking on the Network Management menu located at the top section of the IPAM Interface.

  • To add a DNS Appliance, click the plus button located at the top left corner of the DNS view. While creating an object for DNS Appliance, user should select the object type as “TCPWave Remote”. Enter IP Address (TCPWave Remote”) in the text field to auto fill host name and domain name.

  • When the user clicks on plus button, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.

  • Firewall Template: When the user associates the firewall template to the appliance, the configuration data is sent to the remote, update-firewall.sh script and iptables are restarted. When DNS/DHCP/IPAM appliance is updated with SNMP ACLs, by taking the configuration from associated firewall template, it updates the firewall rules configuration file with SNMP ACLs and sends to the remote.

  • When the firewall template association is changed for an appliance, the associated ACLs are taken from that appliance constructing the new firewall configuration file and sending it to the remote. When the firewall template gets self-updated, the list of appliances where the updated firewall template is associated constructing new configuration file is sent to the respective appliances.

  • User can select SNMP ACLs on the create/edit appliance page on the Monitoring tab.

Users can schedule the add/update/clone/delete and sync operations on a preferable date and time. During the creation of DNS appliance, once the user enters the relevant data in the fields and clicks OK, a pop-up appears – Please select OK to add now or Schedule to add later. On clicking Schedule, a Schedule Add Operation pop-up appears.

Enter the Job ID, Execute On (GMT) and Time along with the description and click OK.

The scheduled job appears in the Scheduler Management section of the Administration tab. Users can schedule one-time job for add appliances operation.

Tab 1: Appliance Configuration

Input Field Label

Mandatory

Description

DNS Appliance Type

Yes

Select one of the DNS Appliance types from the dropdown. The dropdown list includes

  1. ISC BIND

  2. Authoritative Appliance

  3. ISC BIND Cache Appliance

  4. UNBOUND Cache Appliance

  5. NSD Authoritative Appliance (These appliances can only be slaves due to the inability to accept the dynamic updates.)

  6. DNS Proxy Appliance

Stealth Appliance

No

Select Yes when the DNS Appliance is a hidden master.

Internal Cache Appliance

No

This field is applicable for Cache appliances. By default, it is checked and it acts as an Internal Cache appliance which points to internal roots. If unchecked, it will take the external root hints from Internet Root Hints page to resolve the external domains.

Enable Automatic DNSDR

No

This field is applicable only for Internal BIND Cache appliances. When this field is checked, an internal BIND Cache appliance will be auto converted to standalone master when root appliances are not reachable for certain time interval (DNSDR configuration generation and send to remote server time interval, DNSDR Grace Time Interval). To enable recursion on standalone master, user can enable the global option (Enable Recursion on DNSDR Mode) from Global Policy Management page.

Service DMZ Visible Zones from Internal Network

No

This field is applicable only for External Cache appliances which are pointing to Internet Root Hints. By default, this option is enabled. When it is enabled, user can resolve the internal zones from external cache appliance which have DMZ visible options enabled in zone.

Enable Recursion

No

BIND Authoritative appliance can act as a Cache appliance to resolve Internal or External domains. While creating an appliance, user has the flexibility to select BIND AUTH appliance as a CACHE by enabling the Recursion check box. Once recursion check box is enabled, it will ask for the Internal Cache resolution or External resolution. By default, it is set to Internal Cache appliance.
When a BIND AUTH appliance is recursion enabled, it can resolve the non-managed zones from AUTH appliance.
Constraints on AUTH+CACHE creation for Internal Cache Appliances:
1. To create an AUTH+CACHE appliance, at least one root appliance needs to be defined.
2. Stealth appliance cannot act as an AUTH+CACHE appliance and vice versa.
3. NSD is a slave only appliance in TCPWave IPAM, so it cannot act as AUTH+CACHE appliance.
4. Root zone cannot be deleted if there is at least one AUTH+CACHE appliance defined.

Auto Restore Configurations

No

If there is any mismatch between the configuration files on IPAM and a particular remote, then the configuration files are updated automatically when this option is checked. These checks depend on the value defined in “Configuration Sync Time Interval” global option and the mismatched files on remote will be replaced by files on IPAM after the configuration checks. The list of files checked on the remote for mismatch are:

named: /opt/tcpwave/chroot/etc/named.conf
nsd: /opt/tcpwave/nsd/etc/nsd.conf
unbound: /opt/tcpwave/etc/unbound/unbound.conf
firewall: /opt/tcpwave/etc/firewall.conf
ntp: /opt/tcpwave/etc/ntp.conf
snmp: /opt/tcpwave/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf
syslog: /etc/rsyslog.conf
tacacs: /etc/pam.d/sshd
sshdconfig: /opt/tcpwave/etc/sshd_config
zebraconfig: /opt/tcpwave/etc/zebra.conf
bgpd: /opt/tcpwave/etc/bgpd.conf
ospfd: /opt/tcpwave/etc/ospfd.conf
resolver: /etc/resolv.conf
banner: /etc/issue

This option is available for BIND AUTH, BIND Cache, UNBOUND Cache and BIND AUTH+Cache appliances. When this checkbox is enabled, DNS queries are encrypted and the privacy, security between the clients and resolvers is improved.

Tab 7: SYSLOG-NG

The Syslog-NG tab has five sub tabs under it. The values defined in these tabs are updated in the syslog-ng configuration file. User can view the Syslog-NG configuration file at /etc/syslog-ng/syslog-ng.conf.

Syslog-NG Options

User can change the syslog-ng options from this tab. Changes made to the option values in this tab will affect in the options section of syslog-ng.conf file after submitting the details. If value is not provided for any of the options, the default value will be set for that option. When the user clicks on Syslog-NG options icon, the following fields appear:

Input Field Label

Mandatory

Default Value

Accepted Values

Description

Time to wait before re-opening dead connections

No

60

> 0

The time to wait in seconds before a dead connection is re-established.

Time to wait before closing idle connections

No

60

> 0

If no new messages are written to a destination within the specified time in seconds, the connection will be closed and its state will be freed.

Messages to buffer before writing

No

60

> 0

Specifies how many lines are flushed to a destination at a time. The syslog-ng OSE application waits for this number of lines to accumulate and sends them off in a single batch. Increasing this number increases throughput as more messages are sent in a single batch, but also increases message latency.

Time to wait between statistics messages

No

600

> 0

syslog-ng OSE periodically sends a log statistics message. The message will be sent after specified time interval in seconds. This message contains statistics about the received messages, and about any lost messages since the last such message. It includes a processed entry for every source and destination, listing the number of messages received or sent, and a dropped entry including the IP address of the server for every destination where syslog-ng has lost messages. The center (received) entry shows the total number of messages received from every configured sources.

Number of messages to buffer

No

1000

> 0

The number of messages that the output queue can store.

Maximum log message size

No

2048

> 0

The maximal length of the log messages is limited by this option. It is not recommended to set the option value higher than 10 MB.

Keep live time-stamp

No

Yes

Yes/No

Specifies whether syslog-ng should accept the timestamp received from the sending application or client. If disabled, the time of reception will be used instead.

Tab 9: Network Configuration – This tab is enabled after DNS appliance is created.

Network Configuration enables user to create/edit/delete physical interfaces, virtual interfaces and bonding interfaces on TCPWave DNS Appliances.

In TCPWave DNS appliance page, go to Network Configuration tab to perform above operations on interfaces present on the appliance. Existing interfaces on the appliance are displayed initially after creation of DNS appliance.

Adding Virtual Interface:

User can create virtual interface of lookback and bond interfaces and can also sync rules and routes from Remote to IPAM.

Note: Before making any update in NICs, sync network interfaces configurations from Remote to IPAM.

A button Add Virtual Interface is used to create virtual interface (VIP) of network interface (NIC).

This button will be enabled after selecting one of the NIC form network interfaces grid.

Note: Virtual interface of loopback interface must create in separate network.

Example: If we have ethX and bondX interfaces in 192.168.0.0/24 network then loopback VIPs can be in another network like 192.193.215.72/31 network.


Prerequisites to create a Network Interface:

By default, only eth0 interface is configured when the user configures the Remote appliance for the first time. The user can manage the configurations of all the NICs from Network Configuration screen. User must ensure that there is an additional NIC before creating an NIC otherwise IPAM will not allow the user to create an NIC.

Policy Based Routing

Policy Based Routing (PBR) is a technique that forwards and routes data packets based on policies or filters. Network administrators can selectively apply policies based on specific parameters such as source and destination IP address, source or destination port, traffic type, protocols, access list, packet size, or other criteria and then route the packets on user-defined routes.

Advantages of Policy Based Routing

With Policy Based Routing, user can define route policies.

For example, there is a network with IP 10.1.10.0, Gateway (router address) 10.1.10.1 and its network interfaces are eth0 (10.1.10.22) and eth1 (10.1.10.23). When the router gets a packet from the network (10.1.10.0) for sending it to eth1 (10.1.10.23), router will find its destination address (10.1.10.23) and send them via default route (10.1.10.1).

To send the packets via different route, user has to define policies or configure policy based routing.

Configure Policy Based Routing

Select an NIC/VIP/bond and click Configure Policy Based Routing. When the user clicks on this button, a details screen is displayed. User can add/modify rule and route file configuration from this window.


Appliance Routing Tables

Routing tables contain all the routes of destination and source address. There are four default routing tables: local, main, default, unspec. User cannot modify or delete the default routing tables. User can create custom routing tables by clicking plus button in Appliance Routing tables grid. When the user clicks on plus button, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.

Input Field Label

Mandatory

Description

Code

Yes

Enter a valid table unique code in between 0 and 225.

Table Name

Yes

Enter a valid table name.


After entering the required details, click OK. The created appliance routing table is added to the grid.

User can modify the routing table by selecting an existing custom routing table and clicking Edit. Make the necessary changes and click OK.

User can delete the routing table by selecting an existing custom routing table and clicking Delete.


Routing Configuration

Add the rule and route configurations in rule-ethX and route-ethX files from Network interfaces grid. Select one of the ethX network interface and click Configure Policy Based Routing, this opens a popup with text area fields. Add valid syntax in both files and click Ok. Please make sure that the rule and route files have been created successfully in the IPAM or Remote machine.


IP Routing Information

This is a read-only grid that displays the routes information of network interfaces.

Modifying DNS Appliance

  • To edit a DNS Appliance, Select the DNS Appliance and click the Edit button located at the top left corner of the DNS view.

  • When the user clicks Edit, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.

Users can schedule the add/update/clone/delete and sync operations on a preferable date and time. During the editing of DNS appliance, once the user enters the relevant data in the fields and clicks OK, a pop-up appears – Please select OK to add now or Schedule to add later. On clicking Schedule, a Schedule Edit Operation pop-up appears.

Enter the Job ID, Execute On (GMT) and Time along with the description and click OK.

  • The scheduled job appears in the Scheduler Management section of the Administration tab. Users can schedule one-time job for edit appliances operation.


Tab 1: Appliance Configuration

Input Field Label

Mandatory

Description

DNS Appliance Type

Yes

Select one of the DNS Appliance types from the dropdown. The dropdown list includes

  1. ISC BIND Authoritative Appliance

  2. ISC BIND Cache Appliance

  3. UNBOUND Cache Appliance

  4. NSD Authoritative Appliance (These appliances can only be slaves due to the inability to accept the dynamic updates.)

  5. DNS Proxy Appliance

Stealth Appliance

No

Select Yes when the DNS Appliance is a hidden master.

Internal Cache Appliance

No

This field is applicable for Cache appliances. By default, it is checked and it acts as an Internal Cache appliance which points to internal roots. If unchecked, it will take the external root hints from Internet Root Hints page to resolve the external domains.

Enable Automatic DNSDR

No

This field is applicable only for Internal BIND Cache appliances. When this field is checked, an internal BIND Cache appliance will be auto converted to standalone master when root appliances are not reachable for certain time interval (DNSDR configuration generation and send to remote server time interval, DNSDR Grace Time Interval). To enable recursion on standalone master, user can enable the global option (Enable Recursion on DNSDR Mode) from Global Policy Management page.

Service DMZ Visible Zones from Internal Network

No

This field is applicable only for External Cache appliances which are pointing to Internet Root Hints. By default, this option is enabled. When it is enabled, user can resolve the internal zones from external cache appliance which have DMZ visible options enabled in zone.

Enable Recursion

No

BIND Authoritative appliance can act as a Cache appliance to resolve Internal or External domains. While creating an appliance, user has a flexibility to select BIND AUTH appliance as a CACHE by enabling the Recursion check box. Once recursion check box is enabled, it will ask for the Internal Cache resolution or External resolution. By default, it will be set to Internal Cache appliance.
When a BIND AUTH appliance is recursion enabled, it can resolve the non-managed zones from AUTH appliance.
Constraints on AUTH+CACHE creation for internal cache appliance:
1. To create an AUTH+CACHE appliance, at least one root appliance needs to be defined.
2. Stealth appliance cannot act as an AUTH+CACHE appliance and vice versa.
3. NSD is a slave appliance, so it cannot act as AUTH+CACHE appliance.
4. Root zone cannot be deleted when there are at least one AUTH+CACHE appliance defined.

Auto Restore Configurations

No

If there is any mismatch between the configuration files on IPAM and a particular remote, then the configuration files are updated automatically when this option is checked. These checks depend on the value defined in “Configuration Sync Time Interval” global option and the mismatched files on remote will be replaced by files on IPAM after the configuration checks. The list of files checked on the remote for mismatch are:

named: /opt/tcpwave/chroot/etc/named.conf
nsd: /opt/tcpwave/nsd/etc/nsd.conf
unbound: /opt/tcpwave/etc/unbound/unbound.conf
firewall: /opt/tcpwave/etc/firewall.conf
ntp: /opt/tcpwave/etc/ntp.conf
snmp: /opt/tcpwave/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf
syslog: /etc/rsyslog.conf
tacacs: /etc/pam.d/sshd
sshdconfig: /opt/tcpwave/etc/sshd_config
zebraconfig: /opt/tcpwave/etc/zebra.conf
bgpd: /opt/tcpwave/etc/bgpd.conf
ospfd: /opt/tcpwave/etc/ospfd.conf
resolver: /etc/resolv.conf
banner: /etc/issue

Enable DNS over TLS

No

This option is available for BIND Auth, BIND Cache, Unbound Cache and BIND Auth+Cache appliances. When this checkbox is enabled, DNS queries are encrypted and the privacy, security between the clients and resolvers is improved.

Tab 6: SYSLOG-NG

The Syslog-NG tab has five tabs under it. The values defined in these tabs are updated in the syslog-ng configuration file. User can view the Syslog-NG configuration file at /etc/syslog-ng/syslog-ng.conf.

Syslog-NG Options

User can change the syslog-ng options from this tab. Changes made to the option values in this tab will affect in the options section of syslog-ng.conf file after submitting the details. If value is not provided for any of the options, the default value will be set for that option. When the user clicks on Syslog-NG options icon, the following fields appear:

Input Field Label

Mandatory

Default Value

Accepted Values

Description

Time to wait before re-opening dead connections

No

60

> 0

The time to wait in seconds before a dead connection is re-established.

Time to wait before closing idle connections

No

60

> 0

If no new messages are written to a destination within the specified time in seconds, the connection will be closed and its state will be freed.

Messages to buffer before writing

No

60

> 0

Specifies how many lines are flushed to a destination at a time. The syslog-ng OSE application waits for this number of lines to accumulate and sends them off in a single batch. Increasing this number increases throughput as more messages are sent in a single batch, but also increases message latency.

Time to wait between statistics messages

No

600

> 0

syslog-ng OSE periodically sends a log statistics message. The message will be sent after specified time interval in seconds. This message contains statistics about the received messages, and about any lost messages since the last such message. It includes a processed entry for every source and destination, listing the number of messages received or sent, and a dropped entry including the IP address of the server for every destination where syslog-ng has lost messages. The center (received) entry shows the total number of messages received from every configured sources.

Number of messages to buffer

No

1000

> 0

The number of messages that the output queue can store.

Maximum log message size

No

2048

> 0

The maximal length of the log messages is limited by this option. It is not recommended to set the option value higher than 10 MB.

Keep live time-stamp

No

Yes

Yes/No

Specifies whether syslog-ng should accept the timestamp received from the sending application or client. If disabled, the time of reception will be used instead.


Syslog-NG Sources

This tab shows source options for syslog-ng with checkbox beside each option. After selecting the checkbox, it will show the parameters for that source as fields. Clicking on the Add/Update button will insert/edit the source in the right-side grid. s_sys is the default source with Internal and System source options. After submitting the details, syslog-ng.conf file is updated with the sources from the grid. When the user clicks on Syslog-NG Sources icon, the following fields appear:

Tab 9: Network Configuration

Network Configuration enables user to create/edit/delete physical interfaces, virtual interfaces and bonding interfaces on TCPWave DNS Appliances.

In TCPWave DNS appliance page, go to Network Configuration tab to perform above operations on interfaces present on the appliance. Existing interfaces on the appliance are displayed initially after creation of DNS appliance.


Prerequisites to create a Network Interface:

By default, only eth0 interface is configured when the user configures the Remote appliance for the first time. The user can manage the configurations of all the NICs from Network Configuration screen. User must ensure that there is an additional NIC before creating an NIC otherwise IPAM will not allow the user to create an NIC.

User can create NIC/VIP from this tab by clicking plus button in Network Interfaces grid. When the user clicks on plus button, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.

Change Duplex Settings

Select an NIC/VIP/bond interface and click Change Duplex Settings button present on the Network Interface grid. When the user clicks on Change Duplex Settings button, a details screen is displayed.


  1. If user selects “Enables Auto-Negotiate” option, then NIC will take default speed and duplex type.

  2. If user selects “Enables Half Duplex” or “Enables Full Duplex” option then dropdown value will change according to duplex type. Speed dropdown values depend on NICs. The values supported by NIC are shown in the speed dropdown. Speed dropdown is a dynamic dropdown, it will change according to NICs and their duplex type. If NIC does not support half duplex then half duplex radio button will be hidden.


Network Configuration button

Policy Based Routing

Policy Based Routing (PBR) is a technique that forwards and routes data packets based on policies or filters. Network administrators can selectively apply policies based on specific parameters such as source and destination IP address, source or destination port, traffic type, protocols, access list, packet size, or other criteria and then route the packets on user-defined routes.

Advantages of Policy Based Routing

With Policy Based Routing, user can define route policies.

For example, there is a network with IP 10.1.10.0, Gateway (router address) 10.1.10.1 and its network interfaces are eth0 (10.1.10.22) and eth1 (10.1.10.23). When the router gets a packet from the network (10.1.10.0) for sending it to eth1 (10.1.10.23), router will find its destination address (10.1.10.23) and send them via default route (10.1.10.1).

To send the packets via different route, user has to define policies or configure policy based routing.

Configure Policy Based Routing

Select an NIC/VIP/bond and click Configure Policy Based Routing. When the user clicks on this button, a details screen is displayed. User can add/modify rule and route file configuration from this window.


Appliance Routing Tables

Routing tables contain all the routes of destination and source address. There are four default routing tables: local, main, default, unspec. User cannot modify or delete the default routing tables. User can create custom routing tables by clicking plus button in Appliance Routing tables grid. When the user clicks on plus button, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.



Input Field Label

Mandatory

Description

Code

Yes

Enter a valid table unique code in between 0 and 225.

Table Name

Yes

Enter a valid table name.


After entering the required details, click OK. The created appliance routing table is added to the grid.

User can modify the routing table by selecting an existing custom routing table and clicking Edit. Make the necessary changes and click OK.

User can delete the routing table by selecting an existing custom routing table and clicking Delete.


Routing Configuration

Add the rule and route configurations in rule-ethX and route-ethX files from Network interfaces grid. Select one of the ethX network interface and click Configure Policy Based Routing, this opens a popup with text area fields. Add valid syntax in both files and click Ok. Please make sure that the rule and route files have been created successfully in the IPAM or Remote machine.


IP Routing Information

This is a read-only grid that displays the routes information of network interfaces.

Cloning a DNS Appliance

  • To Clone a DNS Appliance, Select the DNS Appliance and click the Clone button located at the top left corner of the DNS view.

  • When the user clicks on Clone button, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.

Users can schedule the add/update/clone/delete and sync operations on a preferable date and time. During the cloning of DNS appliance, once the user enters the relevant data in the fields and clicks OK, a pop-up appears – Please select OK to add now or Schedule to add later. On clicking Schedule, a Schedule Add Operation pop-up appears.

Enter the Job ID, Execute On (GMT) and Time along with the description and click OK.

The scheduled job appears in the Scheduler Management section of the Administration tab. Users can schedule one-time job for add appliances operation.

> 0

If no new messages are written to a destination within the specified time in seconds, the connection will be closed, and its state will be freed.

Messages to buffer before writing

No

60

> 0

Specifies how many lines are flushed to a destination at a time. The syslog-ng OSE application waits for this number of lines to accumulate and sends them off in a single batch. Increasing this number increases throughput as more messages are sent in a single batch, but also increases message latency.

Time to wait between statistics messages

No

600

> 0

syslog-ng OSE periodically sends a log statistics message. The message will be sent after specified time interval in seconds. This message contains statistics about the received messages, and about any lost messages since the last such message. It includes a processed entry for every source and destination, listing the number of messages received or sent, and a dropped entry including the IP address of the server for every destination where syslog-ng has lost messages. The center (received) entry shows the total number of messages received from every configured source.

Policy Based Routing

Policy-based routing (PBR) is a technique that forwards and routes data packets based on policies or filters. Network administrators can selectively apply policies based on specific parameters such as source and destination IP address, source or destination port, traffic type, protocols, access list, packet size, or other criteria and then route the packets on user-defined routes.


Advantages of Policy Based Routing

With Policy Based Routing, user can define route policies.

For example, there is a network with IP 10.1.10.0, Gateway (router address) 10.1.10.1 and its network interfaces are eth0 (10.1.10.22) and eth1 (10.1.10.23). When the router gets a packet from the network (10.1.10.0) for sending it to eth1 (10.1.10.23), router will find its destination address (10.1.10.23) and send them via default route (10.1.10.1).

To send the packets via different route, user has to define policies or configure policy based routing.

Configure Policy Based Routing

Select an NIC/VIP/bond and click Configure Policy Based Routing. When the user clicks on this button, a details screen is displayed. User can add/modify rule and route file configuration from this window.


Appliance Routing Tables

Routing tables contain all the routes of destination and source address. There are four default routing tables: local, main, default, unspec. User cannot modify or delete the default routing tables. User can create custom routing tables by clicking plus button in Appliance Routing tables grid. When the user clicks on plus button, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.

DNS Full Configuration Sync

DNS full configuration sync will update the remote with DNS configuration files and zone files and reloads the DNS service or restarts the DNS service based on the appliance type or global option value of a Faster Sync. Full sync will update the system configuration files like SNMP, TACACS+, sshd, Banner, monitrc, syslog, BGP/OSPF and ZEBRA etc. when values are given while creating an appliance. The process of DNS full sync in TCPWave IPAM is discussed below:

1. When a request is received for DNS full sync for an appliance, it will read the appliance related information from database like appliance template, option template, firewall template and rpz templates. If the appliance is authoritative appliance, then it will read all managed zones information.

2. Once the data is collected from the database, using multi-threading it will create DNS config and zone files.

3. Once the config file and zone files are created, those configuration files are validated for syntax checks. If the syntax is wrong for any config file or a zone, then sync will fail immediately.

4. Once the config files are validated successfully, it will execute one custom script on the IPAM before sending it to the remote.

5. Once the custom script is executed successfully, it will create ZIP file from all the generated configuration files and paths of the config files on the remote.

6. Once the ZIP file is generated, it will convert that ZIP file to Base64 string and send it to the remote via TCPWave secure tunnel.

Once the remote DNS full config data is received, it will do the following steps:

1. When full config data is received on the remote, it will first check whether the DNS service is running or not on the remote, if not running or multiple DNS services are running then DNS full sync will fail with DNS service exception.

2. If DNS service runs on the remote, then it will read the DNS config paths from the full sync message and create the respective folders on the remote if they do not exist.

3. Once the folders are created on the remote, it will convert the Base64 string into ZIP file.

4. Once the ZIP file is created, it will UNZIP that ZIP file and create a temp folder with all those configs.

5. Once the UNZIP is success, using multi-threading it will copy all the config files and zone files to respective DNS folders.

6. Once the config files are copied to the respective folders, it will reload/restart the DNS service to make the DNS service up to date with the latest configs.

7. For BIND AUTH appliances, if the zone is managed by this remote, then it will run RNDC FREEZE and THAW commands as a separate thread.

8. Once the DNS service is reloaded, it will send a success/fail message to the IPAM to update the DNS full sync status in the database.

Scheduling DNS Sync Operation

User can schedule DNS appliance sync operation by clicking on Network Management -> DNS Management -> DNS Appliances -> Right click the DNS appliance -> select DNS and click Sync -> Schedule.

User can schedule the sync operation Daily/Weekly/Monthly/Repetitive/One time. After entering all the details, click OK to create the scheduled job. The scheduled job executes for the time set while creating scheduled job and performs the DNS appliance sync operation.

User can view the list of scheduled jobs by right clicking on DNS appliance and selecting Scheduled Syncs. User can also delete the scheduled jobs from this page by right clicking on the scheduled job and selecting Delete option. The scheduled job will be removed from the list.

Sync All

User can sync all the DNS appliances at a time by clicking on the Sync All button. Last Sync Time on the appliance grid is updated after the sync operation is completed.

Pre and Post Sync Plugins

Pre and post sync plugins if exist are executed while performing sync on DNS/DHCP appliance. Process Sync Plugins global option enables the execution of pre and post sync plugins.

In case of latency in response while executing the scripts, the execution of these plugins will timeout after the time interval mentioned in the global option Appliance Sync plugin timeout. The error file path to log errors can be changed in the global option Appliance Sync error file path.

“Fail on DNS Sync Failure Plugin” and “Fail on DHCP Sync Failure Plugin” global options control the failure of DNS/DHCP sync on failure of the execution of plugins.

User needs to create plugins with the following names and place them in the directory mentioned in the global option “Appliance Sync plugins path”.

  1. twc-dns-pre-conf-gen-plugin (or twc-dhcp-pre-conf-gen-plugin): This plugin will execute before the creation of configuration file of DNS or DHCP appliance. This plugin will be executed on the IPAM.

  2. twc-dns-pre-conf-upload-plugin (or twc-dhcp-pre-conf-upload-plugin): This plugin will execute before the upload of the configuration file. This plugin will be executed on the IPAM.

  3. twc-dns-post-conf-download-plugin (or twc-dhcp-post-conf-download-plugin): This plugin will execute after the upload of the configuration file. This plugin will be executed on the remote.

  4. twc-dns-post-conf-gen-plugin (twc-dhcp-post-conf-gen-plugin): This plugin will execute after the remote is updated with the new configuration. This plugin will be executed on the remote.

Based on the values set in the following global options, pre and post sync plugins work:

Global Option

Value

Description

Process Sync Plugins

Yes/No

Controls the execution of scripts during sync.

Appliance Sync plugin timeout

1-30

Appliance Sync plugin time out (seconds). Accepts a value between 1 and 30.

Appliance Sync plugins path


/opt/tcpwave/extras

It contains the path where the custom script files will be present.

Appliance Sync error file path

/opt/tcpwave/extras

It contains the path where the error files from custom script execution will be present.

Fail on Appliance Sync failure plugin

Yes/No

Controls the execution of sync when plugin execution fails.

Fail on DNS Sync Failure Plugin

Dropdown

Comma separated list of sync plugins for DNS.

Fail on DHCP Sync Failure Plugin

Dropdown

Comma separated list of sync plugins for DHCP.



If the sync plugin contains /opt or /tcpwave or /opt/tcpwave/ in it, then the plugin will not execute and gives this error: TIMS-1478: Configuration changes to the TCPWave IPAM’s core directory are not permitted.

Import DNS appliances from CSV

Clicking on this button navigates the user to Import DNS appliances page. DNS appliances can be imported with input CSV file.

Manage Services

TCPWave IPAM supports Manage Services, a mechanism that is useful in managing multiple appliance services at one place. User can select one appliance or multiple appliances and click Manage Service button. Stunnel service is disabled when multiple appliances are selected and clicked on Manage services. A modal window ‘Manage services’ will be opened. Manage services allow user to perform service operations i.e. start/stop/restart on one or multiple appliances at a time. In Active Appliance grid, user can see the active appliances and services for them as Active (green) or Inactive (red).

Manage Services provides the following options:

Operation

  1. Start - To start a service on an appliance.

  2. Stop - To stop a service on an appliance.

  3. Restart - To restart a service on an appliance.

Services

Provides all relevant services for DNS and DHCP appliances.

  1. For DNS appliance - DNS, Monit, SSH, BGP, OSPF, Zebra, SNMP, NTP, TIMS-DNS, Stunnel

  2. For DHCP appliance - DHCP, Monit, SSH, BGP, OSPF, Zebra, SNMP, NTP, TIMS-DHCP

Perform Operation

Provides the following ways to perform start/stop/restart operations:

  1. Sequentially - In sequential operations, each device will be operated sequentially. One device will complete the execution of all the selected services then the next device will start operating (One thread at a time)

  2. Simultaneously - In Simultaneous operation, multiple execution threads will be started at a time (one thread for each appliance). No device will wait for another device to start its service execution. However, Stop/Start/Restart of sub services in each appliance like SNMP, BGP etc. will be executed in sequence internally (Multiple threads at a time)



Button section has 3 options:

  1. Submit - To submit the Service start/stop/restart request.

  2. Schedule - To schedule the Service start/stop/restart request later.

  3. Cancel - To Cancel the operation and close the module window.

Active Appliances Grid:

Active Appliance grid under Manage Services provides the list of all selected appliances which are alive. This grid provides current status (active (Green) or inactive (Red)) of every service like DNS, DHCP, MONIT etc, for selected appliance. In grid, user can uncheck an appliance on which he does not want to execute any service. This list can be exported to PDF/CSV/Excel.

DNS-over-TLS

DNS over TLS (DoT) is a security protocol for encrypting and wrapping Domain Name System (DNS) queries and answers via the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. The goal of the method is to increase user privacy and security by preventing eavesdropping and manipulation of DNS data via man-in-the-middle attacks.

Traditional DNS queries and responses are sent over UDP or TCP without encryption. This is vulnerable to eavesdropping and spoofing (including DNS-based Internet filtering). Responses from recursive resolvers to clients are the most vulnerable to undesired or malicious changes, while communications between recursive resolvers and authoritative name servers often incorporate additional protection.

To address these problems, TCPWave offers DNS resolution over TLS-encrypted TCP connections as specified by RFC 7858. DNS-over-TLS improves privacy and security between clients and resolvers. This complements DNSSEC and protects DNSSEC-validated results from modification or spoofing on the way to the client.

DNS Tunnel Detection

DNS Tunnel Detection snapshot logic continuously monitors tcpdump when DNS tunnel detection is enabled on the DNS appliance. DNS tunnel detection can be enabled on BIND Cache, Unbound and BIND Auth+Cache appliances by right clicking on live appliance and enabling/disabling DNS Tunnel Detection present in the context menu. Detection logic drops the SRV and PTR records from the analysis. It considers the queries whose full query/subdomain lengths are greater than the given thresholds and the domains whose number of unique queries exceeds the threshold.

When a domain or domains are detected as possible tunnel domains, monitoring engine will be triggered to create a critical alert.

User is given the flexibility to define the thresholds to determine the possibility of the DNS tunnel. Below are the global options that can be modified.

Global Option

Default Value

Description

Threshold FQDN Length In DNS Query To Detect Possible DNS Tunnel

50

Threshold length of the FQDN in the DNS query to detect and alert possible DNS Tunnel when the length of the FQDN crosses the given value. Accepts a value between 5 and 10,000.

Threshold Subdomain Length In DNS Query To Detect Possible DNS Tunnel

20

Threshold length of a subdomain in the DNS query to detect and alert possible DNS Tunnel when the length of any one of the subdomains or the query crosses the given value. Accepts a value between 5 and 10,000.

Threshold Query Count Per Domain To Detect Possible DNS Tunnel

100

Threshold query count per domain to detect and alert possible DNS Tunnel when the query count crosses the given value. Accepts a value between 1 and 100000.

Microsoft DNS Appliances

TCPWave supports agentless integration with Microsoft appliances using the WinRM (Windows Remote Management) feature.

Overview

Today’s enterprise infrastructure is dynamic, with new geographical locations and the networks associated with them being added or deleted on an ever-increasing basis. Microsoft represents network topology with directory objects called sites and subnets. The current state of the global network may not be reflected correctly within Microsoft Active Directory (AD). This causes an inefficient allocation of Windows services, or even outright outages of basic services such as user authentication and file availability. Microsoft does not offer tools to reveal and resolve such serious issues. TCPWave IP Address Management (IPAM) provides a seamless integration with Microsoft AD Sites and Services to bridge that gap.

Microsoft DNS Appliance
TCPWave uses Microsoft’s WinRM to communicate with Microsoft DNS and DHCP servers and leverages Microsoft’s LDAP interface to communicate with AD, so no software agents are needed on Microsoft servers. Windows Remote Management (WinRM) is the Microsoft implementation of WS-Management Protocol, a standard Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP)-based, firewall-friendly protocol that allows hardware and operating systems. The modern Java enabled TCPWave IPAM uses this technology to execute PowerShell commands on a remote Windows server using WinRM. When TCPWave IPAM is integrated with Microsoft AD, it also has the capability to integrate with Microsoft’s DNS and DHCP services. The zones created in the TCPWave IPAM are managed on the Microsoft DNS appliance. Whenever user creates new records under a zone, the records present in the MS DNS appliance are deleted and replaced with records created in the TCPWave IPAM during the creation of zone in the TCPWave IPAM or during force sync/server sync.

TCPWave and Microsoft AD integration provides:

  1. Bidirectional management of AD sites, network subnets, and AD site relationships.

  2. Ability to quickly move subnets between AD sites within TCPWave.

  3. Ability to assign new network subnets created in TCPWave to a Microsoft AD site.

  4. Visibility into the domain and AD site relationships.

  5. Visibility into networks not assigned to an AD site.

  6. Logging of AD site-specific data.

TCPWave facilitates the process for Quick Integration
The initial configuration of TCPWave and Microsoft integration is simplified by an easy-to-follow wizard that helps as a quick guide to the administrative team through the process of establishing communication between the two systems. TCPWave uses role-based access controls based on Microsoft AD groups to determine which administrative teams are authorized to make changes within the TCPWave tool set.

When TCPWave first communicates with Microsoft AD Sites and Services, it imports the current AD site configuration. From then on, any networks created within TCPWave and assigned to an AD site will be synchronized within Microsoft AD Sites and Services.

Non-Managed DNS Masters


Non-Managed DNS Masters supports non-Managed DNS servers master zones of different clients in TCPWave DNS appliances as slave zones. Non-Managed zones data will reside only on TCPWave DNS appliances /opt/tcpwave/chroot/var/named/zones/slaves folder. The DNS Cache Fault Tolerance feature of the TCPWave IPAM takes the periodic backups of these zone files to handle the disaster recovery of the DNS internal cache appliances.

User can add, edit, delete, list and get operations for the Non-Managed DNS Masters. DNS Full Sync option is provided in the context menu to update all the IPAM managed slaves with external zone information to get the AXFR/IFXR from masters.

Along with External DNS, a new page called Non-Managed DNS Zones is introduced to show the zones and its resource records on TCPWave IPAM present on PowerDNS. A drop-down menu is added in the Non-Managed DNS Masters page, where user can select whether to create any External DNS master or specific PowerDNS.

User can add, edit, delete, list and get operations for the Non-Managed DNS Zones. On context menu a new option, Force Sync is provided to force sync the zone from the external masters and update the IPAM managed slaves forcefully to update the slaves. These updates will lead to DNS configuration changes on TCPWave DNS slaves.

This feature allows the user to add, edit, delete, list and get operations for the Non-Managed DNS Masters and zones. User can add the Non-Managed DNS Zones from the GUI, zone name, at least one master and slave selection are mandatory if the Zone type is External DNS. Zone Type fields contains two values, External DNS or PowerDNS. If user selects PowerDNS, a new tab is displayed where user can view zone resource records.

Anycast DNS

Overview

Anycast DNS is a tremendous way to improve the performance and resiliency of your DNS architecture whether you are an ISP or private enterprise. In this overview, we’ve shown at a high-level what Anycast is and how it works in theory. Additionally, we’ll discuss the pros and cons of using static routing as a means to achieving an Anycast DNS design.

Anycast is the use of routing and addressing policies to affect the most efficient path between a single source and several geographically dispersed targets that “listen” to a service within a receiver group.  In Anycast, the same IP address space is used to address each of the listening targets (DNS Appliances in our case).  Layer 3 routing dynamically handles the calculation and transmission of packets from our source (DNS Client) to its most appropriate (DNS Appliance) target. 

The diagram below shows an example of Anycast DNS.  A single DNS client workstation, configured with the Anycast DNS IP address of 10.10.10.10, is shown performing DNS resolution against its “closest” of three DNS appliances deployed using the same Anycast IP address.

The client’s DNS resolver can resolve against any one of the three DNS Appliances shown above. According to the drawing above, layer 3 routing would send DNS client’s packets through router R1 due to the routing topology. Should router R1 or Appliance A fail, DNS client’s packets would automatically be rerouted to the next nearest DNS Appliance via routers R2 and R3, and so forth. Additionally, the route to Appliance A, would be removed from the routing tables, thus preventing further use of that nameAppliance. Appliance A won’t be used until it is restored, and the IP Anycast address routes reinjected to the network.

Anycast, Unicast, Multicast?

Unicast is one source that can “talk” to a service that is advertised or hosted on one (1) node configured with a globally unique IP address. The source will always talk to that target node when configured and told to do so. Traditional DNS deployments use unicasting. DNS clients are configured with different combinations of unicast addresses of DNS Appliances that are deployed.

Anycast is one source that can “talk” to a service that is advertised or hosted on multiple nodes configured with the same IP Address.  Layer 3 routing will route the packets to the “nearest” target based upon topology.

Multicast is one-to-many.  Multicast consists of a source that delivers a service to multiple nodes using a Multicast Group Address.  The main difference in Multicast and Anycast is that the source is a transmitter of a service and it is distributed via layer 3 using specially allocated IP Address group addressing.  A common use of multicast is streaming audio where the audio is published via Multicast Addressing and clients pick up the routed stream as a channel.

The basic requirements for Anycast DNS

The following list is a basic set of requirements and recommendations for supporting Anycast DNS:

  • Injection of Anycast IP address (es) into the routed network – This can be accomplished using either static routes or using routing protocols such as RIP, OSPF, or BGP.

  • Host-based routing software that supports one of the major routing protocols such as Quagga Routing Software.

  • Clients should be configured to resolve DNS queries via the Anycast address(es)

  • DNS appliances should listen to DNS requests on the Anycast IP addresses

  • DNS appliances should be configured with at least one Anycast IP address on a loopback interface. Additionally, the Appliance should be configured with a management IP which can be either a physical or an additional loopback interface.

  • At least one physical IP must be defined for the exchange of routing information, as well as, system access and maintenance in the absence of the routes to the Anycast IP address (es).

  • DNS appliances should be configured to use the physical or management IP addresses for zone-transfers, zone updates, and/or query-source because replies might go to a different Appliance than intended.

What are the benefits of Anycast DNS?

Benefit

Description

Increased Reliability

Anycast improves reliability of DNS through the placement of multiple geographically dispersed Appliances at the same IP address. The redundancy of these DNS Appliances makes the service more highly available and reliable.

Load Balancing

Dynamic layer 3 routing of Anycast IP Addresses will effectively load balance DNS queries especially over equal cost route paths.

Improved Performance

Packets destined for Anycast DNS Appliances will be routed to the “nearest” Appliance in the topology. This helps ensure that DNS clients are querying their local Appliances first before using remote Appliances based upon routing and topology.

Enhanced Security

Geographically dispersed DNS Appliances that operate using the same IP address makes the DNS service more resilient to DDoS attacks because it’s much tougher to launch attacks on hosts that use duplicated IP address schemes that reside in different parts of the network.

Localized Impact of DoS Attacks

Successfully launched DdoS attacks will typically be localized and only affect a portion of the entire Anycast DNS group.

Simplified Client Configuration

Anycast DNS can dramatically simplify the configuration of all DNS client resolvers. It’s possible to use the same DNS appliance IP Addresses for all DNS client resolvers. Configuring DHCP templates for dynamically configured hosts, as well as, imaging or hand-configuring static configured IP clients would be dramatically simplified.

Increased Availability

A DNS Anycast Appliance that becomes unavailable due to failure or routine maintenance will have very little impact on name resolution service because the service routes are withdrawn from the routing tables.  Routing will divert this traffic to new alternate best path Appliances in the Anycast group.



Drawbacks of using Anycast

While there are many benefits to Anycast, there are some potential drawbacks. One could argue that Anycast is:

  1. More complex to deploy

  2. Anycast is more expensive in terms of deployment time, money, and use of IP address space

  3. Anycast DNS is more difficult to manage and troubleshoot

  4. Monitoring Anycast is also more difficult

Default DNS resolver behavior

DNS client resolvers can be configured with multiple DNS appliance targets. Resolvers vary based upon operating systems and have different time outs. Common DNS resolver behavior is to use the first Appliance in the list. The client resolver will make a distinction between a negative response and no response.  In the event the resolver doesn’t receive any response (positive or negative), it will typically wait a time out value before it switches to the second Appliance in the resolver list. The next time the resolver has to perform a look up though, it won’t “remember” that the first Appliance in the list was non-responsive.  On subsequent queries the resolver will start querying with the first Appliance in the list even though it is unavailable. We’ll see the same time out as it switches to the next DNS appliance in the list. Depending on the operating system of the client, this could be 1-5 seconds as it “rotates” through the resolver list each time, attempting the failed Appliance.

How Anycast DNS improves on this behavior?

Anycast DNS virtually eliminates this issue. TCPWave’s DNS client resolver is configured with Anycast IP Address (es) that map to a group of Anycast DNS Appliances. As shown above, if one of the Anycast DNS Appliances in the list were to go down, routing would redirect the requests to an alternate Anycast DNS that is configured in the same Anycast Group. The failover process is handled by the routing protocol used in the deployment of Anycast. In some cases, the delay or time out to the resolver is negligible and undetectable from an end-user perspective.

Anycast Routing Protocols

TCPWave IPAM supports two types of Anycast Protocols namely Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) and Open Shortest Path First (OSPF). The following section describes the two protocols in detail.

Border Gateway Protocol (BGP)

Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is a standardized exterior gateway protocol designed to exchange routing and reachability information between autonomous systems (AS) on the Internet. The protocol is often classified as a path vector protocol but is sometimes also classed as a distance-vector routing protocol. The Border Gateway Protocol makes routing decisions based on paths, network policies, or rule-sets configured by a network administrator and is involved in making core routing decisions.

Most Internet service providers must use BGP to establish routing between one another (especially if they are multihomed). Very large private IP networks use BGP internally. An example would be the joining of a number of large OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) networks where OSPF by itself would not scale to size. Another reason to use BGP is multihoming a network for better redundancy, either to multiple access points of a single ISP or to multiple ISPs.

DNS Appliances in Anycast BGP Network

TCPWave DNS appliances provide Anycast functionality that can utilize BGP thus converting them into BGP routers. They can then participate in the BGP Anycast network by establishing connections with BGP peers and exchanging routing information with them.

Open Shortest Path First (OSPF)

Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) is a routing protocol for Internet Protocol (IP) networks. It uses a link state routing algorithm and falls into the group of interior routing protocols, operating within a single autonomous system (AS). It is defined as OSPF Version 2 in RFC 2328 (1998) for IPv4. The updates for Ipv6 are specified as OSPF Version 3 in RFC 5340 (2008).

OSPF is perhaps the most widely used interior gateway protocol (IGP) in large enterprise networks. Intermediate System to Intermediate System (IS-IS), another link-state dynamic routing protocol, is more common in large service provider networks. The most widely used exterior gateway protocol is the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP), the principal routing protocol between autonomous systems on the Internet.

DNS Appliances in Anycast OSPF Network

TCPWave DNS appliances provide Anycast functionality that can utilize OSPF routing protocol and thus converting them into OSPF routers. They can then participate in the OSPF Anycast network by establishing connections with OSPF peers and exchanging routing information within a single autonomous system.

Anycast DNS (BGP) in TCPWave IPAM

Overview

TCPWave IPAM supports DNS Cache appliances with Anycast networking via Quagga routing suite. Quagga is a network routing software suite providing implementations of Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) and Border Gateway Protocol (BGP).

The Quagga architecture consists of a core daemon (zebra) which is an abstraction layer to the underlying kernel. The following steps explain how to enable anycast in the TCPWave DNS Cache appliances.

Steps to create Cache DNS Appliance with BGP

To create a cache only DNS Appliance, user needs to create a BIND Cache Appliance Template. Go to DNS Appliance Template Screen and select the Appliance Type as ISC BIND Cache Appliance, enter the template name and click OK.

To create a new cache only DNS Appliance, user should create an object of type “TCPWave Remote”.

In the popup dialog window, type the following details in their respective fields.

When a BIND AUTH appliance is recursion enabled, it can resolve the non-managed zones from AUTH appliance.
Constraints on AUTH+CACHE creation:
1. To create an AUTH+CACHE appliance, at least one root appliance needs to be defined.
2. Stealth appliance cannot act as an AUTH+CACHE appliance and vice versa.
3. NSD is a slave only appliance in TCPWave IPAM, so it cannot act as AUTH+CACHE appliance.
4. Root zone cannot be deleted if there is at least one AUTH+CACHE appliance defined.

Auto Restore Configurations

No

If there is any mismatch between the configuration files on IPAM and a particular remote, then the configuration files are updated automatically when this option is checked. These checks depend on the value defined in “Configuration Sync Time Interval” global option and the mismatched files on remote will be replaced by files on IPAM after the configuration checks. The list of files checked on the remote for mismatch are:

named: /opt/tcpwave/chroot/etc/named.conf
nsd: /opt/tcpwave/nsd/etc/nsd.conf

Tab 7: SYSLOG-NG

The Syslog-NG tab has five sub tabs under it. The values defined in these tabs are updated in the syslog-ng configuration file. User can view the Syslog-NG configuration file at /etc/syslog-ng/syslog-ng.conf.

Syslog-NG Options

User can change the syslog-ng options from this tab. Changes made to the option values in this tab will affect in the options section of syslog-ng.conf file after submitting the details. If value is not provided for any of the options, the default value will be set for that option. When the user clicks on Syslog-NG options icon, the following fields appear:

Input Field Label

Mandatory

Default Value

Accepted Values

Description

Time to wait before re-opening dead connections

No

60

> 0

The time to wait in seconds before a dead connection is re-established.

Time to wait before closing idle connections

No

60

> 0

If no new messages are written to a destination within the specified time in seconds, the connection will be closed and its state will be freed.

Messages to buffer before writing

No

60

> 0

Specifies how many lines are flushed to a destination at a time. The syslog-ng OSE application waits for this number of lines to accumulate and sends them off in a single batch. Increasing this number increases throughput as more messages are sent in a single batch, but also increases message latency.

Time to wait between statistics messages

No

600

> 0

syslog-ng OSE periodically sends a log statistics message. The message will be sent after specified time interval in seconds. This message contains statistics about the received messages, and about any lost messages since the last such message. It includes a processed entry for every source and destination, listing the number of messages received or sent, and a dropped entry including the IP address of the server for every destination where syslog-ng has lost messages. The center (received) entry shows the total number of messages received from every configured sources.

Number of messages to buffer

No

1000

> 0

The number of messages that the output queue can store.

Maximum log message size

No

2048

> 0

The maximal length of the log messages is limited by this option. It is not recommended to set the option value higher than 10 MB.

Keep live time-stamp

No

Yes

Yes/No

Specifies whether syslog-ng should accept the timestamp received from the sending application or client. If disabled, the time of reception will be used instead.

Tab 10: Forwarders

The internal cache Appliances resolve only to the zones present in the IPAM. If a user wants to resolve to an external zone using internal cache Appliance, then the user should add the external zones in the DNS forwarders tab in edit DNS Appliance screen.

This Forwarders tab is enabled only when the DNS Appliance is an internal cache Appliance. It is disabled for the external cache Appliances.

Click on Add to create a forward only zone (external zone not managed by TCPWave IPAM) and give the required information. IPv4 or IPv6 address is mandatory to create a DNS forwarder.

OSPF

Overview

OSPF stands for Open Shortest Path First. OSPF is a dynamic routing protocol used to build larger scale IP networks. OSPF is a link-state routing protocol that calculates the shortest path to other networks. Taking the bandwidth of the network links into account, it uses cost as its metric. OSPF works by developing adjacencies with its neighbors, periodically sending hello packets to neighbors, flooding changes to neighbors when a link’s status changes, updating its neighbors of all recent link state changes every 30 minutes. The use of this algorithm makes OSPF much faster at network convergence.

Steps to create Cache DNS Appliance with OSPF

To create a cache only DNS Appliance, user needs to create a BIND Cache Appliance Template. Go to DNS Appliance Template Screen and select the Appliance Type as ISC BIND Cache Appliance, enter the template name and click OK.

To create a new cache only DNS Appliance, user should create an object of type “TCPWave Remote”.

In the popup dialog window, type the following details in their respective fields.

Tab 1: Appliance Configuration

Input Field Label

Mandatory

Description

DNS Appliance Type

Yes

Select one of the DNS Appliance types from the dropdown. The dropdown list includes

  1. ISC BIND Authoritative Appliance

  2. ISC BIND Cache Appliance

  3. UNBOUND Cache Appliance

  4. NSD Authoritative Appliance (These appliances can only be slaves due to the inability to accept the dynamic updates.)

  5. DNS Proxy Appliance

Stealth Appliance

No

Select Yes when the DNS Appliance is a hidden master.

Internal Cache Appliance

No

This field is applicable for Cache appliances. By default, it is checked and it acts as an Internal Cache appliance which points to internal roots. If unchecked, it will take the external root hints from Internet Root Hints page to resolve the external domains.

Enable Automatic DNSDR

No

This field is applicable only for Internal BIND Cache appliances. When this field is checked, an internal BIND Cache appliance will be auto converted to standalone master when root appliances are not reachable for certain time interval (DNSDR configuration generation and send to remote server time interval, DNSDR Grace Time Interval). To enable recursion on standalone master, user can enable the global option (Enable Recursion on DNSDR Mode) from Global Policy Management page.

Service DMZ Visible Zones from Internal Network

No

This field is applicable only for External Cache appliances which are pointing to Internet Root Hints. By default, this option is enabled. When it is enabled, user can resolve the internal zones from external cache appliance which have DMZ visible options enabled in zone.

Enable Recursion

No

BIND Authoritative appliance can act as a Cache appliance to resolve Internal or External domains. While creating an appliance, user has the flexibility to select BIND AUTH appliance as a CACHE by enabling the Recursion check box. Once recursion check box is enabled, it will ask for the Internal Cache resolution or External resolution. By default, it is set to Internal Cache resolution.
When a BIND AUTH appliance is recursion enabled, it can resolve the non-managed zones from AUTH appliance.
Constraints on AUTH+CACHE creation:
1. To create an AUTH+CACHE appliance, at least one root appliance needs to be defined.
2. Stealth appliance cannot act as an AUTH+CACHE appliance and vice versa.
3. NSD is a slave only appliance in TCPWave IPAM, so it cannot act as AUTH+CACHE appliance.
4. Root zone cannot be deleted if there is at least one AUTH+CACHE appliance defined.

Auto Restore Configurations

No

If there is any mismatch between the configuration files on IPAM and a particular remote, then the configuration files are updated automatically when this option is checked. These checks depend on the value defined in “Configuration Sync Time Interval” global option and the mismatched files on remote will be replaced by files on IPAM after the configuration checks. The list of files checked on the remote for mismatch are:

named: /opt/tcpwave/chroot/etc/named.conf
nsd: /opt/tcpwave/nsd/etc/nsd.conf
unbound: /opt/tcpwave/etc/unbound/unbound.conf
firewall: /opt/tcpwave/etc/firewall.conf
ntp: /opt/tcpwave/etc/ntp.conf
snmp: /opt/tcpwave/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf
syslog: /etc/rsyslog.conf
tacacs: /etc/pam.d/sshd
sshdconfig: /opt/tcpwave/etc/sshd_config
zebraconfig: /opt/tcpwave/etc/zebra.conf
bgpd: /opt/tcpwave/etc/bgpd.conf
ospfd: /opt/tcpwave/etc/ospfd.conf
resolver: /etc/resolv.conf
banner: /etc/issue

VRRP

Overview

VRRP stands for Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol. This feature is applicable to Unbound Cache, DNS BIND Authoritative, Recursive Cache Only Or BIND Auth+Cache DNS appliances. The purpose of DNS HA using keepalived is to provide simple and robust facilities for high-availability in the TCPWave DNS infrastructure.

Steps to create Cache BIND DNS Appliance with VRRP

To create a cache only DNS Appliance, user needs to create a BIND Cache Appliance Template. Go to DNS Appliance Template Screen and select the Appliance Type as ISC BIND Cache Appliance, enter the template name and click OK.

To create a new cache only DNS Appliance, user should create an object of type “TCPWave Remote”.

In the popup dialog window, type the following details in their respective fields.

Internal Cache Appliance

No

This field is applicable for Cache appliances. By default, it is checked and it acts as an Internal Cache appliance which points to internal roots. If unchecked, it will take the external root hints from Internet Root Hints page to resolve the external domains.

Enable Automatic DNSDR

No

This field is applicable only for Internal BIND Cache appliances. When this field is checked, an internal BIND Cache appliance will be auto converted to standalone master when root appliances are not reachable for certain time interval (DNSDR configuration generation and send to remote server time interval, DNSDR Grace Time Interval). To enable recursion on standalone master, user can enable the global option (Enable Recursion on DNSDR Mode) from Global Policy Management page.

Service DMZ Visible Zones from Internal Network

No

This field is applicable only for External Cache appliances which are pointing to Internet Root Hints. By default, this option is enabled. When it is enabled, user can resolve the internal zones from external cache appliance which have DMZ visible options enabled in zone.

Enable Recursion

No

BIND Authoritative appliance can act as a Cache appliance to resolve Internal or External domains. While creating an appliance, user has the flexibility to select BIND AUTH appliance as a CACHE by enabling the Recursion check box. Once recursion check box is enabled, it will ask for the Internal Cache resolution or External resolution. By default, it is set to Internal Cache resolution.
When a BIND AUTH appliance is recursion enabled, it can resolve the non-managed zones from AUTH appliance.
Constraints on AUTH+CACHE creation:
1. To create an AUTH+CACHE appliance, at least one root appliance needs to be defined.
2. Stealth appliance cannot act as an AUTH+CACHE appliance and vice versa.
3. NSD is a slave only appliance in TCPWave IPAM, so it cannot act as AUTH+CACHE appliance.
4. Root zone cannot be deleted if there is at least one AUTH+CACHE appliance defined.

No

DNS DMZ

Overview

DMZ stands for demilitarized zones. In computer security, a DMZ or demilitarized zone (sometimes referred to as a perimeter network) is a physical or logical subnetwork that contains and exposes an organization’s external-facing services to a usually larger and untrusted network, usually the Internet. The purpose of a DMZ is to add an additional layer of security to an organization’s local area network (LAN); an external network node only has direct access to equipment in the DMZ, rather than any other part of the network. The name is derived from the term “demilitarized zone”, an area between nation states in which military operation is not permitted.

TCPWave IPAM supports DMZ feature for both BIND cache and Unbound Cache Appliances which can be enabled from the zones screen and DNS Appliance screen. If the DMZ is enabled for the zone, then this zone can be resolved from external cache Appliances.

For DMZ to work, there should be at least one internal cache Appliance, one master DNS Appliance and one root Appliance.

Enabling DMZ

  • The user can enable DMZ in the zone screen. In order to enable the DMZ, user should click Network Management -> DNS Infrastructure -> Managed DNS Zones -> click Add /Edit to enable DMZ.

  • Select the organization from the drop down. Enter the name of the zone to be created, select the zone template to be associated from the drop down and enable DMZ option. DMZ option in zone screen takes Yes/No.

  • If DMZ Visibility is Yes, then all the DMZ DNS Internet Cache Appliance’s configuration will be updated with this zone and reloaded.

  • If DMZ Visibility is NO, then zone cannot be resolved from External DNS DMZ cache Appliances, it can only be resolved from Internal Cache Appliances.

  • External BIND cache and unbound cache Appliances have a parameter called “Service DMZ Visible Zones from Internal Network: Yes/No”. If it is YES, then it can resolve to both external zones and some internal zones which are managed by TCPWave IPAM. If it is NO, it can only resolve to the external zones.

  • When a user creates DMZ zone, the option “Service DMZ Visible Zones from Internal Network” must be set to Yes for the internal zone to be resolved by the cache Appliance.

  • When the user queries for the DMZ zone on external BIND cache or unbound cache Appliance, it resolves to the internal master DNS Appliance instead of giving the public IP.

Disabling DMZ

  • The user can disable the DMZ option for a particular zone by clicking on Network Management -> DNS Infrastructure -> Managed DNS Zones -> click Edit to disable DMZ.

  • Now, if the user queries for the DMZ disabled zone on BIND cache or external unbound cache Appliance, it resolves to the public IP.

  • If the user wants to disable DMZ from external cache Appliances, it can be done as follows: Click on Network Management -> DNS Infrastructure -> DNS Appliances -> Select the external cache Appliance and click Edit -> Change the option “Service DMZ Visible Zones from Internal” to No -> Click on OK.

DNSDR

Overview

The scope of the Cache to Master (DNSDR) functionality is to convert a given cache DNS Appliance as a standalone emergency master. No manual intervention of the administrator is needed to perform DNSDR operation on the remote TCPWave Cache appliances. When the communication between the root Appliances and cache Appliances is lost, the TCPWave Cache appliances automatically switch to emergency standalone master DNS Appliance.

For example, an earth quake occurred in China as a result of which there is no connection between the root Appliances and cache Appliances, TCPWave Cache can become a standalone DNS Master for all DNS forward and Reverse Zones.

  • IPAM user will never be able to invoke a DNSDR from the IPAM with any GUI Action.

  • If root Appliances are not reachable and if Grace Time = X min passes and if Enable automatic DNSDR is set to true in Cache appliance, then the Cache will self-invoke DNSDR.

  • User can set the global policy, “DNSDR configuration generation and send to remote Appliance time interval” in order to generate the DNSDR configuration and send it to remote in the given time interval.

  • If Enable DNSDR is set to false, then the user will login to the cache as root and execute dodnsdr command to initiate DNSDR manually. To revert back DNSDR, execute undodnsdr command on the cache appliance.

  • When the Cache is initially created, all the DR files are generated and copied. There will never be a manual copy from IPAM to caches. Every 24 hours, these files are regenerated by the IPAM.

  • When root DNS Appliances are reachable, the standalone master is converted back to the regular cache.

DNSDR has no DNSSEC functionality. The Emergency standalone master will have plain non-DNSSEC zones.

Procedure to Set DNSDR

  1. When IPAM is started, one internal thread starts that will be executed after 2 min of IPAM restart for the first time. A global option (“DNSDR configuration generation and send to remote Appliance time interval”) can be used to setup the time interval. This thread sends the DNSDR configuration to all the Internal Cache Appliances.

  2. To set this global option, user should click the Administration -> Configuration Management -> Global Policy Management -> DNS -> DNSDR configuration generation and send to remote Appliance time interval > Set time in hours

  3. This global option takes a value between 1 and 5040(1 month). User can set the remote Appliance time interval using this global option. If this value is set to 1, then the DNSDR configuration will be generated and sent to remote Appliance in 1 hour.

  4. There is another global option to set the DNSDR grace time interval. When this option is set, the DNSDR waits for the time interval set and if there is no connection between the cache and root Appliance, DNSDR will be initiated and cache becomes emergency stand-alone master. This global option takes the Time interval (in minutes).

  5. To set this option, user should click the Administration -> Configuration Management -> Global Policy Management -> DNS -> DNSDR Grace Time Interval -> Set time in minutes

  6. On the remote, based on the Appliance running, user can find DNSDR configuration files in the respective folders. If DNS is named, the user can find the DNSDR configuration files in the path “/opt/tcpwave/chroot/DNSConfFilesBackups/DNSDR”, if it is UNBOUND, the path is “/opt/tcpwave/etc/unbound/DNSConfFilesBackups/”.

  7. User can dig for a zone before switching to master. The answer section is displayed below.

[root@antlia-187 DNSDR] # dig @localhost tcpwave1.com

«» DiG 9.9.8-P2 «» @localhost tcpwave1.com (2 Appliances found)

global options: +cmd Got answer: -»HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 222 flags: qr rd ra ad; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 1

; OPT PSEUDOSECTION: EDNS: version: 0, flags: udp: 4096;

QUESTION SECTION: tcpwave1.com. IN A

; AUTHORITY SECTION: tcpwave1.com. 60 IN SOA nmxqrdc-qrs01-.510984.tcpwave.com. john.smith.tcpwave.com. 2016052024 21600 ‘600 604800 86400

; Query time: 701 cosec; APPLIANCE: 127.0.0.1453(127.0.0.1) ; WHEN: Thu Jun 09 12:20:23 GMT 2016 MSG SIZE rcvd: 117


  • When a switch from Cache to Master happens, the script “/opt/tcpwave/scripts/dodnsdr” runs automatically. This will stop the running cache Appliance, copy the DNSDR configuration files to named folders and start named.

  • After the switch, user can dig for the zone associated to the master DNS Appliance. Go to Network Management -> DNS Management -> DNS IPv4 Appliances -> Cache Appliance > Dig for Zones

[root@antlia-187 scripts] # dig @localhost tcpwave1.com

«» DiG 9.9.8-P2 «» @localhost tcpwave1.com (2 Appliances found) ; global options: +cmd ; Got answer: ; -»HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 50091 ; flags: qr as rd; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 0, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 1 ; WARNING: recursion requested but not available

; OPT PSEUDOSECTION: EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 4096 ; QUESTION SECTION: tcpwavel.com. IN A

; AUTHORITY SECTION: tcpwave1.com. 86400 IN SOA ntlia-187.tcpwave.com. john.smith.tcpwave.com. 2016052012 21600 3600 60480 I 86400

; Query time: 0 cosec ; APPLIANCE: 127.0.0.1#53(127.0.0.1) ; WHEN: Thu Jun 09 12:35:17 GMT 2016 ; MSG SIZE rcvd: 107


  • Once the DNS is switched to Master, Monit config will also change, monit will now monitor the named.

  • When the switch back to Cache Appliance happens, the script “/opt/tcpwave/scripts/undo-dnsdr” runs automatically on the cache Appliance. This will stop the DNS master named service and starts the cache Appliance.

  • Once the DNS is switched to Cache, Monit config will also change back to original configuration. Now monitor will monit the Cache DNS Appliance.



DNS Views

Overview

  1. TCPWave IPAM supports views, a mechanism that’s very useful in firewalled environments. Views allow you to present one DNS appliance configuration to one community of hosts and a different configuration to another community.

  2. A zone can be shared across multiple views or can be associated with a single view. The list of views is ordered. The default view always falls at the bottom of the list.

  3. A zone can be associated to only those views that are common across all the master Appliances for that zone.

  4. On the remote DNS Appliance, all zone files for any given view will be placed under a view specific folder.

  5. User can Enable or Disable Views from the Global Options (Enable DNS Views: Yes/No).

Enabling/Disabling Views

  • User can enable/disable views from the global options by clicking on Administration -> Configuration Management -> Global Policy Management -> DNS -> Enable DNS Views -> Change the value to Yes /No for enabling/disabling DNS Views in the IPAM.

  • The view screens in the product appear only when the DNS Views is enabled in the global options.

User can create/clone/edit/delete the DNS Views from the “Views” page. This page appears only when the DNS Views is enabled in the global options.

Views

User can create/clone/edit/delete the DNS Views from the “Views” page. This page appears only when the DNS Views is enabled in the global options.

Adding DNS View

To add a Zone in the IPAM, go to Network Management menu located at the top section the IPAM Interface -> DNS Management-> DNS Zones -> DNS Views.


To add a DNS View

  • Click on the Add button located at the top left corner of the DNS View grid.

  • When the user clicks on Add button, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.

Yes (If Match Destinations field is empty)

Yes (If Match Clients field is empty.)

Enter IP Address/ACL for allow notify value.

  • A View name must be unique i.e. it should not clash with an existing view in the same organization.

  • A view name cannot be changed once it is created. User can modify the Match clients or Match destinations information.

  • After entering all the details, click the OK button.

  • The created DNS View is added to the list.
