GEO-IP

The GeoIP feature uses the MaxMind GeoIP Country Downloadable Database to identify the country of origin of HTTP requests, based on the request’s IP address. The GeoIP feature supports the MaxMind IPv4 and IPv6 country database. Geo-IP in IPAM restricts the request from the non Access Control Lists.

Enabling the GeoIP feature

To enable the GeoIP feature, follow the below steps:

  1. Go to Global Policy Management.

  1. Click DNS from left menu and search for “Enable DNS Views”.

  2. Click Edit icon of the global option and select Yes from the dropdown.

  4. Click Submit.

  5. DNS Views page is now available in the path Network Management >> DNS Management >> DNS Zone >> DNS Views.

Adding Countries

To add restricted countries in Geo-IP,

  1. Navigate to Network Management >> DNS Management >> DNS Zone >> DNS Views.

  2. Click Plus icon.

  3. Select the Organization to map the restricted countries

  4. Enter View Name

  5. Click Match clients text field.

  6. Generated Address Match list pop-up window appears,

  1. Select Geo-IP radio button.

  2. From the countries drop-down list, select the countries list and click Add icon.

  3. The selected country is added in the Selected Data list. By default, the country is included.

  4. To exclude the country IP address, select Exclude.

  5. Click OK.

  6. To cancel, click CANCEL.

  7. Selected Countries are displayed in Match Clients field.

  8. Enter Destinations in the field and click OK.

  9. A new row is added in the DNS Views list.

  1. The DNS Views grid consists of the following columns:

  • View Name: Displays the name of the View.

  • Organization: Displays the name of the Organization that is mapped.

  • Match Clients: Displays the restricted country codes.

  • Match Destinations: Displays the destination that is matched with Clients.

  • Created By: Displays the name of the Admin who created/added the country codes to the organization in the system.

  • Created Time: Displays the created time and date of the record.

  • Updated By: Displays the name of the Admin who update the details.

  • Updated Time: Displays the last updated date and time of the record.

The Admin has an option to Add, Clone, Edit, Delete, Bookmark, Refresh, Column Visibility for the selected record.

Views in DNS Appliance Screen

  • Once DNS views are created, they can be associated to the BIND AUTH DNS Appliances. User can associate views to AUTH Appliances by clicking on Network Management -> DNS Management -> DNS Appliances -> Select a BIND AUTH Appliance to enable the views -> Click on Edit -> DNS Views -> Select the DNS Views from the available views to be added and click Add -> User can order the views on the Appliance, ordering is more important in DNS views -> Click on OK

  • Every DNS Appliance has a “default” view. All the zones that are not associated to any view, go into that “default” view.

  • User can modify the DNS Views of a BIND AUTH Appliance by clicking on Network Management -> DNS Management -> DNS Appliances -> Select a BIND AUTH Appliance to modify the views -> Click on Edit -> DNS Views -> Select the DNS Views from the available views to be added or delete the selected views -> User can order the views on the Appliance, ordering is more important in DNS views -> Click on OK

  • NSD Appliance doesn’t support Views. So, the user will not be able to select the NSD as a slave for Views enabled BIND AUTH DNS master Appliances in the zone template screen.

  • User can easily add new views to Appliance. But while deleting a view, if any zone is associated with that view, the user will not be able to delete that view. The user can delete the view only after dissociating it from the zone.

Views in Zones Screen

  • Zone screen contains a tab called views. Based on the selection of zone template, the views are displayed in the views tab.

  • The selection of views will be based on the Master and Slaves Appliances. The views that are present in both Master and Slave are only selected because Master and Slave should communicate and slave should get the updates from master. Once the common views are selected based on the Master and Slave, the selected view is shown in the Resource Record add screen. Resource Record can be associated to only one view. If no view is selected in the zone screen, it will go to “default” view.

  • In order to associate a view to a zone, user should click Network Management -> DNS Management -> Managed DNS Zone -> Add zone / Edit an existing zone -> Select the views in the DNS Views screen -> Click on OK.

  • User will not be able to change the zone template if there are any resource records associated to the selected common views.

Views in Subnet Screen

  • User can enable views in the subnet screen by clicking on Address Space -> IPv4 -> Network -> Subnet -> while creating Subnet/Subnets, user can select the Views to be managed by the subnet in the primary domain page.

  • Based on the selection, objects will go into the respective views.

  • User will not be able to change/disassociate a view from the subnet view selection drop down unless there are objects associated with those views.

Views in Object Screen

  • While creating an object, there will be a drop down for selecting views.

  • User can associate views to object by clicking on Address Space -> IPv4 -> Network -> Subnet -> while creating object, user can select the DNS views.

  • If object’s domain is a primary domain, then user can see all the views which are selected in the subnet screen.

  • If Object’s domain is a secondary domain, then user will not see any drop down for selection of views while creating the object and the object will go to zone which is in the “default” view.

  • All the RRs in the object level will go to object’s view. If no view is selected, then it will go to “default” view.

Root Zone right click options

User can perform the following operations on root zone right click:

  1. Edit – User can edit the root zone with this option.

  2. DNSSEC

  • Disable DNSSEC – User can disable DNSSEC on zone by clicking on this option.

  • Enable DNSSEC – User can enable DNSSEC on zone by clicking on this option.

  • ZSK Key Rollover and KSK Key Rollover – DNSSEC keys are of two types: ZSK (Zone Signing Key) and KSK (Key Signing Key). Each of these keys contain public key and private key. Currently, Key rollover happens when the inactive time of the key is reached without any user intervention. With this manual DNSSEC Key rollover, user can do a key rollover whenever needed.

  1. After selecting one of the two options (ZSK Key Rollover/KSK Key Rollover) in the context menu, the active time of the zones of current key is added with the global option value (Minimum number of days between two Manual Key Rollovers for a zone.). If this value is greater than the present date and time, then manual key rollover is not performed. After this check is successful, a popup will be shown with current key’s inactive and expiry details. If continue is clicked, then manual rollover will be performed for the selected zone and then a popup will be shown displaying the deploy time of newly created keys. The deploy time of new keys depends upon the global option value (Inactive time for old DNSSEC keys on Manual Key Rollover). The present time and the global option values are added and if this value is less than old key’s inactive date then this value is replaced at the inactive date of old keys and this value becomes the deploy time of new keys otherwise inactive date remains the same.

  2. Expire date of the old keys change according to the global option value (Expire time for old DNSSEC keys on Manual Key Rollover). New keys will be created only after inactive time of the current keys.

  1. Add Bookmark – Root zone can be bookmarked using this option.

  2. Force Sync – Force sync operation will be performed on Root zone by clicking on this option.

  3. Status – Displays the status of the root zone on DNS appliance.

  4. Delete – User can delete the root zone by clicking Delete.

DNS Proxy

The devices that are connected to the internet use DNS that makes it vulnerable to cyber-attacks. For example, DNS Cache Poisoning, DNS spoofing, etc. DNS Proxy can be used to avoid such attacks.

DNS Proxy stores the result in the DNS Cache Appliance when it gets a request for the first time. The stored cache is used to get the subsequent requests from the same domain. It helps the network to improve its performance.

DNS Proxy contains a set of regulation that is used to filter the DNS requests that are not accurately structured or the DNS requests that are proved to cause risks.

Need of DNS Proxy

DNS proxy helps mitigate issues such as DNS Cache poisoning that arise in a B2B relationship. The root appliance will delegate the third-party DNS to the DNS Proxy Appliance and the DNS proxy will talk to the third-party DNS and fetch answers.

The flow can be represented in the following sequence of steps.

  • End user computing device queries the DNS Cache remote.

  • DNS cache remote queries the internal root Appliance on behalf of the client.

  • DNS root Appliance responds to the DNS cache with a referral to the DNS proxy Appliance.

  • DNS cache now queries the DNS proxy.

  • DNS proxy queries the third-party DNS.

  • Third party DNS responds to the DNS proxy with an answer.

  • DNS proxy sends the response to the DNS cache remote.

  • DSN cache gives the answer to the end user device.

Another advantage of using a DNS Proxy is that it minimizes the number of firewall ports that a multinational corporation needs to open with third parties.

Adding a DNS Proxy Appliance

  • To create a DNS Proxy Appliance, user should initially create an object of type TCPWave Remote. To create an object, go to Address Space -> IPv4 -> Click on any network to create an object -> click subnet -> Select any IP in the objects screen and click Add button -> Fill all the required details in the create new object dialog box and in the drop down for Object type, select TCPWave Remote -> Click on Ok

  • Create a proxy Appliance template with Dynamic updates enabled, TISG key and loggers: Go to Network management-> Appliance templates -> Click on Add->Select the DNS Appliance type as DNS PROXY APPLIANCE -> Fill the required information -> Click on OK

  • DNS Proxy has default option template, DNS Proxy Default Template. To create a new option template for DNS proxy Appliance, go to Network management-> Option templates -> Click on Add-> Select the DNS Appliance type as DNS PROXY APPLIANCE -> Fill the required information -> Click on OK

  • Create a proxy DNS Appliance: Go to Network management-> DNS Appliances -> Click on Add -> Select the DNS Appliance type as DNS PROXY APPLIANCE -> Fill the required information to create a DNS proxy Appliance -> Click on OK

Modifying DNS Proxy Appliance

  • User can modify the DNS proxy Appliance by clicking on Network Management -> DNS Appliances-> Select DNS proxy Appliance -> Click on Edit -> Modify the required information -> Click on OK

Deleting DNS Proxy Appliance

  • User can delete the DNS proxy appliance by clicking on Network Management -> DNS Appliances -> Select DNS proxy appliance -> Click on Delete

  • User will not be able to delete a DNS proxy appliance if it is referenced in zone template. User can delete the proxy appliance after deleting the proxy root zone.

Adding DNS Proxy Root Zone Delegations to Third Parties

  • The NS records added in the root zone will be referred in the proxy root zone.

  • Add NS record in the proxy root zone with data as owner name of the A record present in the proxy root zone. In order to create NS record, user should initially create A record in the proxy root zone.

  • Go to DNS management->proxy root zone -> Click on Add -> Select the record type as A -> Give owner name and IPv4 address details -> Click on OK

  • To create NS record in proxy root zone: Go to DNS management->proxy root zone -> Click on Add -> Select the record type as NS -> Give data as owner name of the A record present in the proxy root zone -> Click on OK

  • Add the NS record in the root zone with same owner name as in the proxy root zone

  • Go to DNS management-> root zone -> create external NS record in the root zone (give data as proxy Appliance name). User will get an error if there is no NS record with the same owner name in the proxy root zone.

  • Dig for the NS record @ root Appliance: Go to DNS management-> Appliances-> right click root Appliance and dig for the NS record. Answer section of the dig is displayed below,

QUESTION SECTION

: tcpwave.twitter.com. IN A

; AUTHORITY SECTION:

tcpwave.twitter.com. 1200 IN NS ntlia-191.tcpwave.com.

; ADDITIONAL SECTION:

ntlia-191.tcpwave.com. 86400 IN A 10.1.10.191


  • Dig for the NS record at the proxy root appliance. Sync the proxy appliance before doing a dig: Go to DNS management-> Appliances-> right click proxy root appliance and dig for the NS record. Answer section of the dig is displayed below,

QUESTION SECTION

: tcpwave.twitter.com. IN A

; AUTHORITY SECTION:

tcpwave.twitter.com. 86400 IN NS facebook.com.

; ADDITIONAL SECTION:

facebook.com. 86400 IN A 2.0.0.10


  • Dig for the NS record at internal BIND Cache Appliance: Go to DNS management-> Appliances-> right click internal BIND cache Appliance and dig for the NS record. User will get an answer section.

  • User will not be able to modify the NS record in the proxy root zone since it is referred in the root zone.

  • User can add all types of resource records in the proxy root zone.

Active Directory Tab: This tab is enabled when Active Directory Updates is enabled for the zone. User can select either Parent Forest or Child Forest from AD Forest. If Parent Forest is selected, then that AD zone is a standalone Parent forest zone and if Child Forest is selected, then that AD zone is child for the selected Parent forest from the dropdown. User can select the available Domain Controllers and ACLs. Select a domain controller or ACL from the list and click shift right button. The selected domain controllers or ACLs can be seen under Selected Domain Controllers and ACLs list. User can remove the selected ACLs or domain controllers by selecting and clicking on shift left button.

While creating a zone, if the zone name or organization name is changed, ‘Enable Active Directory Updates’ checkbox will be deselected if it was selected previously. When active directory is enabled, the Domain controller objects will be retrieved from the new domain and will be displayed in Available Domain Controllers grid.

To ensure that enterprises have a seamless active directory functionality, TCPWave goes a step further and enforces integrity constraints on the active directory definitions and on the child parent relationships. The access control list policy of which domain controllers can update the underscore zones is determined automatically with an option to override the ACL auto logic using manual intervention.

Entity relationships in the TCPWave Active Directory definition logic follow the rules listed below:

1. In order for a domain controller to be added to the access control list, the domain controller object must be defined as a domain controller.

2. TCPWave provides the ability to control the advertising of the A record of the AD domain using the web interface. For security reasons, the domain controllers cannot advertise dynamic updates into the parent zone.

3. The allow update ACL of the underscore zones is auto calculated. A parent forest will have a policy to permit all the child forests to update the parent.

4. A parent forest domain controller cannot update a child forest using the access control list of definitions.

5. Similarly, one child domain controller cannot update another child forest’s underscore zone.

6. When any domain controller is being actively referenced in any active access control list definitions, the user is not permitted to remove the domain controller object.

7. An administrator can override the access control list definitions that have been calculated automatically by defining a set of access control lists manually. Changes to the ACL’s take place immediately. Administrators are requested to exercise caution while making changes to the access control list definitions.

Resource Record Tab: User can add resource records for the zone from this tab. For more information, refer to Resource Records section.

Extensions: User can add extension to the zone from this tab. For more information refer to Extended Attribute Management section.

  • After entering all the details, click the OK button.

  • The created zone is added to the list.

Cloud Alias Records:

  1. This tab is enabled when the zone template assigned to the zone contains one or more AWS cloud providers.

  2. When a zone with a zone template having one or more AWS cloud providers is being created, AWS Alias resource records will also be imported when the checkbox 'Import Cloud DNS RRs' is checked.

  3. Cloud Alias Records tab displays the list of AWS Alias records.

Creating Cloud Alias Records

  1. User can create new alias records from this tab by clicking the plus button present on the grid. When the user clicks on plus button, a form for adding alias records is displayed with the following fields:

Field Name

Mandatory

Description

Name

Yes

Enter a record name. Example: sandunes.tcpwave.com. Total length of the domain name can be up to 255 characters.

Record Type

Yes

Select a record type from the drop-down. It takes A, CNAME, MX, AAAA, TXT, PTR, SRV, and NAPTR.

Alias Target

Yes

Enter end point from AWS cloud instance.

  1. User can also type the domain name for the resource.

  2. Examples: CloudFront distribution domain name: d111111abcdef8.cloudfront.net

  3. Elastic Beanstalk environment CNAME: example.elasticbeanstalk.com

  4. ELB load balancer DNS name: example-1.us-east-2.elb.amazonaws.com

  5. S3 website endpoint: s3-website.us-east-2.amazonaws.com

  6. Resource record set in this hosted zone: www.example.com

  7. VPC endpoint: example.us-east-2.vpce.amazonaws.com

  8. API Gateway custom regional API: d-abcde12345.execute-api.us-west-2.amazonaws.com

Zone Id

Yes

Enter the hosted zone ID for the AWS resource that you specify in Alias target.

Routing Policy

No

Select a routing policy from the drop-down. It takes Simple, Weight, Latency, Failover, GeoLocation. A traffic policy includes information about the routing configuration that user wants to create, the routing policies that user wants to use and the resources that user wants to route DNS traffic to, such as the IP address of each EC2 instance and the domain name of each ELB load balancer.

Evaluate Target Health

No

It takes Yes/No. Checking the health of resources in complex configurations works much the same way as in simple configurations. However, in complex configurations, you use a combination of alias records (such as weighted alias and failover alias) and non-alias records to build a decision tree that gives you greater control over how Route 53 responds to requests. In general, you should set Evaluate Target Health to Yes for all the alias records in a tree. If you set Evaluate Target Health to No, Route 53 continues to route traffic to the records that an alias record refers to even if health checks for those records are failing.



  1. Enter the data in mandatory fields and click ADD button. AWS cloud alias record is added to the grid.

Modifying Cloud Alias Records

  1. User can modify the existing alias records from Cloud Alias Records tab by clicking on the existing alias records from the list. User can modify the required fields and click UPDATE button. Modified alias record is added to the grid.

Deleting Cloud Alias Records

  1. User can delete the alias record by selecting a record from the list and clicking on Delete button present on the grid. Click OK after deleting the alias record.

Active Directory Tab: This tab is enabled when Active Directory Updates is enabled for the zone. User can select either Parent Forest or Child Forest from AD Forest. If Parent Forest is selected, then that AD zone is a standalone Parent forest zone and if Child Forest is selected then the AD zone is child for selected Parent forest from the dropdown. User can select the available Domain Controllers and ACLs. Select a domain controller or ACL from the list and click shift right button. The selected domain controllers or ACLs can be seen under Selected Domain Controllers and ACLs list. User can remove the selected ACLs or domain controllers by selecting and clicking on shift left button.

While creating a zone, if the zone name or organization name is changed then ‘Enable Active Directory Updates’ checkbox will be deselected if it was selected previously. When active directory is enabled, the Domain controller objects will be retrieved from the new domain and will be displayed in Available Domain Controllers grid.

To ensure that enterprise have a seamless active directory functionality, TCPWave goes a step further and enforces integrity constraints on the active directory definitions and on the child parent relationships. The access control list policy of which domain controllers can update the underscore zones is determined automatically with an option to override the ACL auto logic using manual intervention.

Entity relationships in the TCPWave Active Directory definition logic follow the rules listed below:

1. In order for a domain controller to be added to the access control list, the domain controller object must be defined as a domain controller.

2. TCPWave provides the ability to control the advertising of the A record of the AD domain using the web interface. For security reasons the domain controllers cannot advertise dynamic updates into the parent zone.

3. The allow update ACL of the underscore zones is auto calculated. A parent forest will have a policy to permit all the child forests to update the parent.

4. A parent forest domain controller cannot update a child forest using the access control list of definitions.

5. Similarly, one child domain controller cannot update another child forest’s underscore zone.

6. When any domain controller is being actively referenced in any active access control list definitions, the user is not permitted to remove the domain controller object.

7. An administrator can override the access control list definitions that have been calculated automatically by defining a set of access control lists manually. Changes to the ACL’s take place immediately. Administrators are requested to exercise caution while making changes to the access control list definitions.

Resource Record Tab: You can add resource records for the zone. For more information refer to Resource Records section.

Extensions: You can add extensions to the zone. For more information refer to Extended Attribute Management section.

  • After entering all the details, click the OK button.

  • The cloned zone is added to the list.

Deleting a zone

To delete a DNS Zone in the IPAM, go to Network Management menu located at the top section of the IPAM Interface -> DNS Management -> DNS Zones -> DNS Managed Zones.


To delete a Zone, select a zone and click the delete button located at the top left corner of the DNS view.

Options in Context Menu

User can perform the following operations on zone right click:

Clone: Clone a zone.

DNSSEC:

Disable DNSSEC – User can disable DNSSEC on zone by clicking on this option.

Enable DNSSEC – User can enable DNSSEC on zone by clicking on this option.

DS Record (Delegation of Signing record): Provides information of the signed zone file. Both ZSK and KSK keys will have two different DS records. These records will be placed on the parent zone if they exist otherwise they will be placed on Root Zone.

ZSK Key Rollover and KSK Key Rollover – DNSSEC keys are of two types: ZSK (Zone Signing Key) and KSK (Key Signing Key). Each of these keys contain public key and private key. Currently, Key rollover happens when the inactive time of the key is reached without any user intervention. With this manual DNSSEC Key rollover, user can do a key rollover whenever needed.

  • After selecting one of the two options (ZSK Key Rollover/KSK Key Rollover) in the context menu, the active time of the zones of current key is added with the global option value (Minimum number of days between two Manual Key Rollovers for a zone.). If this value is greater than the present date and time then manual key rollover is not performed. After this check is successful, a popup will be shown with current key’s inactive and expire details. If continue is clicked, then manual rollover will be performed for the selected zone and then a popup will be shown displaying the deploy time of newly created keys. The deploy time of new keys depends upon the global option value (Inactive time for old DNSSEC keys on Manual Key Rollover). The present time and the global option values are added and if this value is less than old keys inactive date then this value is replaced at the inactive date of old keys and this value becomes the deploy time of new keys otherwise inactive date remains the same.

  • Expire date of the old keys change according to the global option value (Expire time for old DNSSEC keys on Manual Key Rollover). New keys will be created only after inactive time of the current keys.

Edit: Please refer to section “Modifying a zone” for more details.

Force Sync: Force sync a zone on DNS appliance.

Sync Zone with Cloud:

This button is enabled when the zone template has at least one cloud provider. When the user clicks “Sync Zone with Cloud”, it fetches the cloud resource records to IPAM. Resource Records can be imported in two ways:

  1. Override zone with cloud - Resource records of IPAM will be overridden with the resource records from selected cloud provider.

  2. Merge zone with cloud - The resource records present in the selected zone in the IPAM will be retained. New resource records from the selected cloud provider will be added to the zone in the IPAM. The resource records with same name in the IPAM will be overridden by the resource records from the cloud.

Import Alias Records:

Import Alias Records button on the zone page is enabled when selected zone is associated to a zone template having one or more AWS cloud providers. Alias Resource Records can be imported in two ways:

  1. Override Records - Alias records of IPAM will be overridden by alias records of all the AWS cloud providers present in the zone template.

  2. Merge Records - The alias resource records present in the selected zone in the IPAM will be retained. New alias records from the AWS cloud providers will be added to the zone in the IPAM. The resource records with same name in the IPAM will be overridden by the resource records from the cloud.

  3. When user selects Merge Zone with Cloud option, a new window pops up and provides the following information to the user:

Non-Alias Resource Records to be Added

Non-Alias Resource Records to be Deleted from the IPAM

Alias Resource Records to be Added

Alias Resource Records to be Deleted from the IPAM




Freeze: Suspend updates to all dynamic zones.

    1. If Zone is not frozen (thawed) on any of the appliances, then “Is Zone Frozen” value will be False.

    2. If Zone is frozen on any of the appliances, then “Is Zone Frozen” value will be true. If zone is frozen, then background will be in frozen blue color and comma separated list of appliances will be displayed on which the zone is frozen.

    3. If the appliances are not reachable or in case user gets any exception while checking if zone is frozen or not, then the value of “Is Zone Frozen” will be N/A.

    4. If status of the zone is not updated, then a message will be displayed saying “Status of this zone is not yet updated”.

    5. DNS sync resets the frozen status of a given zone back to a thawed state.

Monitoring: Enable/Disable

Status: Displays the status of zone.

Thaw: Enable updates to all dynamic zones and reload them.

Delete: Delete the managed DNS zone

Add Bookmark: Add a bookmark for the zone.

Zone Schedule Operations

The Zone Add, Edit, Delete, and Clone operations can now be scheduled at a later time, like the Object level operations. Once the appropriate data is entered for the operation, user has the ability to schedule the operation at a later time using the schedule button.

Underscore Zones

When active directory is enabled for DNS zones, underscore zones are created. User can create resource records in underscore zones. Select an underscore zone, click Edit, and go to Resource Records tab. Select a resource record type from the dropdown, enter the data in mandatory fields, click ADD and click OK. User can modify/delete the resource records from Resource Records tab. User can also import the zone resource records from CSV to the grid.

Regex Search support in Zone Grid

Grid search allows the users to search the data using regular expression term queries.
Note: Regex search can also perform fixed string search.
Example: String ^abc.com$ matches only abc.com.

Meta characters allowed in regex search with examples

Char

Description

Example

*

The asterisk (*) metacharacter is used to match zero (0) or more instances of the strings preceding it

da* will give all strings containing characters "da".

Ex: Da Vinci Code, Daddy's Little Girls.

+

The plus (+) metacharacter is used to match one or more instances of strings preceding it.

mon+ will give all movies containing characters "mon".

Ex: Angels and Demons.

?

The question (?) metacharacter is used to match zero (0) or one instances of the strings preceding it.

com? will give all the categories containing string com.

Ex: comedy, romantic comedy.

.

The dot (.) metacharacter is used to match any single character in exception of a new line.

200. gives all the movies released in the years starting with characters "200" followed by any single character.

Ex: 2005,2007,2008 etc.

[abc]

The charlist [abc] is used to match any of the enclosed characters.

[vwxyz] will give all the movies containing any single character in "vwxyz".

Ex: X-Men, Da Vinci Code, etc.

[^abc]

The charlist [^abc] is used to match any characters excluding the ones enclosed.

^[^vwxyz] will give all the movies containing characters other than the ones in "vwxyz".

[A-Z]

The [A-Z] is used to match any upper-case letter.

[A-Z] will give all the members that have postal address containing any character from A to Z. 

Ex: Janet Jones with membership number 1.

[a-z]

The [a-z] is used to match any lower case letter

[a-z] will give all the members that have postal addresses containing any character from a to z.

Ex: Janet Jones with membership number 1.

[0-9]

The [0-9] is used to match any digit from 0 through to 9.

[0-9] will give all the members have submitted contact numbers containing characters "[0-9]".

Ex: Robert Phil.

^

The caret (^) is used to start the match at beginning.

^[cd] gives all the movies with the title starting with any of the characters in "cd".

Ex: Code Name Black, Daddy's Little Girls and Da Vinci Code.

|

The vertical bar (|) is used to isolate alternatives.

^[cd]|^[u] gives all the movies with the title starting with any of the characters in "cd" or "u".

Ex: Code Name Black, Daddy's Little Girl, Da Vinci Code and Underworld - Awakening.

[[:<:]]

The [[:<:]] matches the beginning of words.

[[:<:]]for gives all the movies with titles starting with the characters.

Ex: Forgetting Sarah Marshal.

[[:>:]]

The [[:>:]] matches the end of words.

ack[[:>:]] gives all the movies with titles ending with the characters "ack".


Ex: Code Name Black.

[[:class:]]

The [[:class:]] matches a character class i.e.[[: alpha:]] to match letters,

[[:space:]] to match white space, [[:punct:]]is match punctuation marks and [[:upper:]] for upper class letters.

[[:alpha:]] gives all the strings containing alphabets only.

Ex: dns zone. 4domain will be omitted by this pattern query.

Managed DNS Reverse Zones

This page displays the list of DNS reverse zones. A default reverse zone is created for all the networks defined in TCPWave IPAM. If the network is associated with a zone template, then the reverse zone will be sent to the managed remotes specified in the zone template. While creating multiple subnets, if “Auto Create Reverse Zones” checkbox is enabled and zone template is associated to the subnets, then managed reverse zones are automatically created and listed in this page.

Creating Managed DNS Reverse Zone

User can create managed DNS reverse zones for the existing subnets by clicking plus button. When the user clicks on plus button, a details form appears with the following fields:

Description

Select a contact from the dropdown.

This checkbox is enabled by default. User can disable monitoring service on a reverse zone by disabling this checkbox.

DMZ Visibility

No

No

No

  • Click OK after entering the required values.

  • Created DNS reverse zone is added to the list.

  • User can schedule the reverse zone add operation by clicking SCHEDULE button in create DNS reverse zone screen. The scheduled job can be a Daily/Weekly/Monthly/Repetitive/One-time job. When a DNS reverse zone create is scheduled, a scheduled job is added in the Scheduler Management page. The time taken is in GMT.

Options in Context Menu

User can perform the following operations on managed reverse zone right click:

  1. Clone: Clone a reverse zone. Please refer to section – “Clone managed DNS reverse zone” for more details.

  2. DNSSEC:

  • Disable DNSSEC – User can disable DNSSEC on reverse zone by clicking on this option.

  • Enable DNSSEC – User can enable DNSSEC on reverse zone by clicking on this option.

  • DS Record (Delegation of Signing record): Provides information of the signed reverse zone file. Both ZSK and KSK keys will have two different DS records. You can export the details of Zone Signing Key (ZSK) and Key Signing Key (KSK) by clicking the download button on the DS Record window. These records will be placed on the reverse zone if they exist otherwise, they will be placed on Root Zone.

  • ZSK Key Rollover and KSK Key Rollover – DNSSEC keys are of two types: ZSK (Zone Signing Key) and KSK (Key Signing Key). Each of these keys contain public key and private key. Currently, Key rollover happens when the inactive time of the key is reached without any user intervention. With this manual DNSSEC Key rollover, user can do a key rollover whenever needed.

  1. After selecting one of the two options (ZSK Key Rollover/KSK Key Rollover) in the context menu, the active time of the reverse zones of current key is added with the global option value (Minimum number of days between two Manual Key Rollovers for a zone.). If this value is greater than the present date and time then manual key rollover is not performed. After this check is successful, a popup will be shown with current key’s inactive and expire details. If continue is clicked, then manual rollover will be performed for the selected reverse zone and then a popup will be shown displaying the deploy time of newly created keys. The deploy time of new keys depends upon the global option value (Inactive time for old DNSSEC keys on Manual Key Rollover). The present time and the global option values are added and if this value is less than old keys inactive date then this value is replaced at the inactive date of old keys and this value becomes the deploy time of new keys otherwise inactive date remains the same.



  1. Expire date of the old keys change according to the global option value (Expire time for old DNSSEC keys on Manual Key Rollover). New keys will be created only after inactive time of the current keys.

  • Edit – Please refer to section – “Modifying managed DNS reverse zones”

  • Force Sync: Force sync a reverse zone on DNS appliance.

  • Freeze: Suspend updates to all reverse zones.

    1. If reverse zone is not frozen (thawed) on any of the appliances, then “Is Zone Frozen” value will be False.

    2. If reverse zone is frozen on any of the appliances, then “Is reverse zone Frozen” value will be true. If reverse zone is frozen, then background will be in frozen blue color and comma separated list of appliances will be displayed on which the reverse zone is frozen.

    3. If the appliances are not reachable or in case user gets any exception while checking if reverse zone is frozen or not, then the value of “Is reverse zone Frozen” will be N/A.

    4. If status of the reverse zone is not updated, then a message will be displayed saying “Status of this reverse zone is not yet updated”.

    5. DNS sync resets the frozen status of a given reverse zone back to a thawed state.

  • Monitoring Enable/Disable

  • Status: Displays the status of the reverse zone on all the managed DNS appliances.

  • Thaw: Enable updates to all dynamic reverse zones and reload them.

  • Delete: Select a reverse zone and click Delete button present in the context menu of reverse zone.

  • Add Bookmark: Select a reverse zone and click Add Bookmark button present in the context menu of reverse zone.

Managed Mirrored Zones

TCPWave customers interesting in cloning the DNS Zone data from a single zone to a cloned zone so that the DNS records of the parent zone are replicated one-to-one in a cloned zone that can leverage the mirrored zone functionality. Using this functionality, the resource record types of the parent zone, that include the A, CNAME, MX, TXT and SRV are mirrored into the cloned zone. The mirrored zones cannot have a parent zone that is enabled for Active Directory. The sub zones of the parent zone do not get mirrored when the parent is mirrored. The dynamic DNS updates that take place to a parent zone cannot be replicated automatically into a mirrored zone. The mirrored zones are automatically monitored by the TCPWave IPAM.

Mirrored zones contain same data as of actual zones to which they are created.

Creating a Mirrored Zone

  1. User can create a mirrored zone by clicking on Network Management -> DNS Management -> DNS Zones -> Mirrored Zones

  2. A Zone for which active directory is disabled, mirrored zone can be created. Multiple mirrored zones can be created at a time for a specific zone by giving comma separated string. Zone dropdown contains zones for which active directory is disabled. TCPWave IPAM doesn’t allow the user to add a mirrored zone with existing zone name or domain name. TCPWave IPAM supports incremental updates for the mirrored zones. After adding/editing/deleting zone, object, resource records, no need of DNS full sync to get mirrored zones dig to work. named.conf file is updated with the mirrored zones at the Zone section containing the same data of the respective zone.

Modifying a Mirrored Zone

Only name of the mirrored zone can be edited. TCPWave IPAM doesn’t allow the user to add a mirrored zone with existing zone name or domain name. After editing the mirrored zone and doing a manual sync for the respective server, user can dig with the mirrored zone name. named.conf file is updated with the mirrored zones at the Zone section containing the same data of the respective zone.

Deleting a Mirrored Zone

Multiple delete of mirrored zones is possible. User can select multiple mirrored zones and click Delete button. After delete and a manual sync, mirrored zone at the zone section in named.conf will be removed.

Global Option

The mirrored zones limit can be set in the global option Maximum mirrored zones limit per Zone. The value can be between 1 and 500 and the default value is 100. If mirrored zones for any Managed zone exceeds this limit, then a warning will be shown.

Validations

Zone Add, Edit and Delete:

A zone cannot be created when a mirrored zone with same name is already present. For a zone containing at least one mirrored zone, active directory cannot be enabled during edit. If a zone containing mirrored zones is deleted, then the mirrored zones assigned to that zone also get deleted automatically.

Organization delete:

If an organization is deleted, then the mirrored zones present in the same organization are also deleted automatically.

Domain Add and Edit:

A domain cannot be created or updated if a mirrored zone with same name already exists.

Non-Managed DNS Zones

Non-Managed DNS Masters supports non managed DNS servers master zones of different clients in TCPWave DNS appliances as slave zones. Non managed zones data will reside only on TCPWave DNS appliances /opt/tcpwave/chroot/var/named/zones/slaves folder. The DNS Cache Fault Tolerance feature of the TCPWave IPAM takes the periodic backups of these zone files to handle the disaster recovery of the DNS internal cache appliances.

User can add, edit, delete, list and get operations for the Non-Managed DNS Masters. DNS Full Sync option is provided in the context menu to update all the IPAM managed slaves with external zone information to get the AXFR/IFXR from masters.

User can add, edit, delete, list and get operations for the Non-Managed DNS Zones. On context menu a new option, Force Sync is provided to force sync the zone from the external masters and update the IPAM managed slaves forcefully to update the slaves. These updates will lead to DNS configuration changes on TCPWave DNS slaves

Along with External DNS, a new page called Non-Managed DNS Zones is introduced to show the zones and its resource records on TCPWave IPAM present on PowerDNS. A drop-down menu is added in the Non-Managed DNS Masters page, where user can select whether to create any external DNS master or specific PowerDNS.

This feature allows the user to add, edit, delete, list and get operations for the Non-Managed DNS Masters and zones. User can add the Non-Managed DNS Zones from the GUI, zone name, at least one master and slave selection are mandatory if the Zone type is External DNS. Zone Type fields contains two values, External DNS or PowerDNS. If user selects PowerDNS, a new tab is displayed where user can view zone resource records.

DNS Configuration

DNS Internet Hints

DNS Internet Root Hints contain public root servers information which is applicable only for external Cache appliances (Internal Cache Appliance option unchecked Cache and recursion enabled authoritative appliances).

Root hints are DNS data stored in a DNS appliance. The root hints provide a list of preliminary resource records that can be used by the DNS service to locate other DNS servers that are authoritative for the root of the DNS domain namespace tree. Root hints are used to prepare servers authoritative for non-root zones so that they can learn and discover authoritative appliances that manage domains located at a higher level or in other subtrees of the DNS domain namespace. These hints are essential for servers authoritative at lower levels of the namespace when locating and finding servers under these conditions.

For example, if a DNS appliance (ServerA.corp.com) is answering a query for a domain, such as the tcpwave.com domain, then ServerA needs some assistance to locate an authoritative appliance (ServerB.tcpwave.com) for this domain. In order for ServerA to find ServerB, or any other servers that are authoritative for the tcpwave.com domain, it needs to be able to query the root servers for the DNS namespace. The root servers can then refer ServerA to the authoritative servers for the [com] domain. The DNS servers for the [com] domain can, in turn, offer ServerA a referral to ServerB or other servers that are authoritative for the tcpwave.com domain.

User can update the Internet root hints by selecting any root hint and clicking Edit.

Sync Internet Cache Servers will update all the Internet DNS Cache servers with the loaded Internet Root Hints.

DNS Log Channels

User can create DNS log channels by clicking on Network Management -> DNS Management -> DNS Configuration ->DNS Log Channels

User can select the Channel type from the drop down, enter channel name, Version and size(MB) of the log channel to be created. Channel type drop down consists of FILE, SYSLOG, STDERR, NULL.

Select a log channel to be modified and click Edit. Make the necessary changes and click Ok. Default log channels cannot be modified/deleted.

Select a log channel and click Delete button to delete the log channel but if the selected log channel is being used, user gets an error until the references are removed.

DNS Host Naming Policies

Introduction

TCPWave IPAM supports ‘Host Naming Policy’ to restrict offensive words in Object Name and Resource Record Owner Name in Object Screen. ‘Host Naming Policy’ functionality will work only when “Enable Host Naming Policies” is enabled in global options.

Creating Host Naming Policy

To create a new Host Naming Policy, user should click Network Management -> DNS Management -> Host Naming Policies.

Click on Add, the screen appears with the following fields.

S. No

Field Name

Description

Name

Name of the Host Naming Policy.

Policy Type

Select the Policy Type from the dropdown. User can select Contains or Regex.

Value

Enter the Value.

Description

Give the description for the Host Naming Policy.



After entering the following details, click Ok to create the Host Naming Policy. Now, try to use the policy value in Object name or Resource record owner name, user will get an error message saying:

“TIMS-9705: The object name bad word that you have entered violates the IPAM Host Naming Convention. Please choose a non-business offensive name.”

Example: Create a Host Naming Policy with the following fields:

S. No

Field Name

Description

Name

Enter the name of the host naming policy.

Policy Type

Contains

Value

Enter the value.

Description

Enter the description for the Host Naming Policy.



Now, create an object with name “brainless” and the user will get an error message. The difference between Policy Types Regex and Contains is,

Regex – Compares the object or owner name with the regex and if the object name contains the regex as a part of the name, it will not allow the user to add the object.

Contains – Compares the object or owner name with the value given in policy and if the object name contains the whole string as the name, then only it will not allow the user to add the object.

Modifying Host Naming Policy

To modify Host Naming Policy, user should click Network Management -> DNS Management -> Host Naming Policies. Select a policy file to be modified and click Edit. Change the fields as required and click Ok.

If the existing Host Naming Policy is updated, then the change will be reflected in the newly created Objects.

Deleting Host Naming Policy

To delete a Host naming policy, click Network Management -> DNS Management -> Host Naming Policies. Select a policy file to be deleted and click Delete.

TCPWave IPAM supports multiple delete of Host Naming Policies at a time.

DNS Security

Active Directory GSS-TSIG Management

Managing Active Directory Domain Services

In TCPWave IPAM, a zone can be enabled to receive dynamic updates from a Microsoft Active Directory Appliance. The dynamic updates can be transferred in GSS-TSIG (Generic Security Service Algorithm for Secret Key Transaction) mode. GSS-TSIG is an extension to the TSIG DNS authentication protocol for secure key exchange. It is a GSS-API algorithm which uses Kerberos for passing security tokens to provide authentication, integrity and confidentiality.

To enable Active Directory updates on a zone, the Enable AD Updates option must be enabled and an existing Domain Controller must be selected while adding or editing a zone. The Enable Secure AD Updates option must be enabled for enabling secure Active Directory updates.

Adding Active Directory User Mapping details

For enabling AD updates on a zone, a Domain Controller information must be added from the Active Directory view in the DNS Management page.

  1. To add Active Directory User Mapping information, go to Active Directory page in the DNS Management in the IPAM.

  2. Click on Add UPN

  3. When the user clicks on Add UPN button, a details screen is displayed. In the details screen, type the following details in their respective fields.

    Field

    Mandatory

    Description

    Organization

    Yes

    Select an organization

    Service

    Yes

    Enter the service name

    Principal Name

    Yes

    Choose a Kerberos Principal name

    Realm

    Yes

    Enter Kerberos Realm name

    Encryption

    Yes

    Enter encryption type

    Principal Type

    Yes

    Choose a Principal type.

    Domain Controller

    Yes

    Choose a Domain Controller Object

    Kerberos KeyTab File

    Yes

    Upload a Kerberos keytab file generated on the Active Directory Appliance.

  4. To generate a Key Tab File, execute the following command on the Active Directory Appliance.
    ktpass –out <Out File name> -princ <Service name>/<Principal name>@<Realm name> -mapuser <Principal name> -pass <Password> -crypto <Encryption type selected> -ptype <Principal type selected>

Deleting Active Directory User Mapping details

To delete a selected Active Directory User Mapping, click Delete UPN button and then click OK to confirm the delete operation.

Validating an Active Directory Mapping

Follow the following procedure to validate an existing Active Directory Mapping information.

    1. Select an Active Directory Mapping information from the Active Directory page in DNS Management in the IPAM.

    2. Click on Validate UPN button.

    3. Click on OK button to confirm validation.

Following the above steps will initiate the Active Directory Mapping validation process. This validation process will take few seconds to complete. Upon completion, the success or fail message is shown.

DNS Threat Management

Firewall Templates
Overview

DNS Firewall prevents connected devices from becoming infected with malware and blocks their activity by enabling recursive DNS Appliances to stop or redirect queries from clients that want to access domains and/or Ips known to be malicious. Compromised devices can be identified and located on the network for rapid neutralization.

DNS Firewall is implemented using iptables. Iptables is used to set up, maintain, and inspect the tables of IP packet filter rules in the Linux kernel. Several different tables may be defined. Each table contains a number of built-in chains and may also contain user-defined chains. Each chain is a list of rules which can match a set of packets. Each rule specifies what to do with a packet that matches. This is called a ‘target’, which may be a jump to the user-defined chain in the same table.

Adding a firewall template

  • Go to Network Management -> DNS Threat Management -> Click on Add to create a new firewall template.

  • User can select an organization from the drop down and fill the name of the template and description.

  • User can add different rules in the firewall template which can be applied to the DNS Appliances for packet filtering. A firewall rule specifies criteria for a packet and a target. If the packet does not match, the next rule in the chain is examined; if it does match, the next rule is specified by the value of the target, which can be one of the special values ACCEPT, DROP, REJECT, QUEUE, LOG or RETURN.

  • User can name the firewall rule. The text given in the Name column will be applied to the Firewall rule.

  • Action takes different values such as

      1. ACCEPT

      2. DROP

      3. REJECT

      4. QUEUE

      5. RETURN

      6. LOG

  • ACCEPT means to let the packet through. DROP means to drop the packet. QUEUE means to pass the packet to user space (if supported by the kernel). RETURN means stop traversing this chain and resume at the next rule in the previous (calling) chain. If the end of a built-in chain is reached or a rule in a built-in chain with target RETURN is matched, then the target specified by the chain policy determines the fate of the packet.

  • Chain takes values like INPUT, FORWARD, OUTPUT

  • Protocol is a set of rules and it contains the list of protocols in the drop down. User can select any one of the protocol or all protocols. It takes all, udp, udplite, icmp, esh, ah, sctp

  • Source is the IPv4 address or IPv4 network to which the firewall rule will be applied. When the “!” argument (invert) is used for source, the sense is inverted.

  • Source port is a port number of the source.

  • Destination is the IPv4 address or IPv4 network to which the firewall rule needs to be mapped. When the “!” argument (invert) is used for destination, the sense is inverted.

  • Destination port is the port number of the destination.

  • Incoming interface is the name of an interface via which a packet is going to be received. For example, eth0.

  • Outgoing interface is the name of an interface via which a packet is going to be sent.

  • Ethernet Address is the valid MAC address.

  • Fragment: User can define firewall filters that handle fragmented packets.

  • Apart from the regular filtering, DNS rules can also be applied. User can create a rule for DNS query or response. If EDNS0 (Extended DNS) is selected, then the user must enter the buffer size.

  • Match String: If the user defines a firewall rule to drop input for all the protocols where the data matches a string “virus”, then this rule will compare the data in the protocols with the match string “virus” and drop the input if the data contains the word in the match string.

  • After providing all the required data, user can click Add Rule.

  • For example, a firewall rule is defined as ACCEPT INPUT from 10.1.10.240 from port 1122 to 10.1.10.60 to port 1443 where protocol is tcp. This firewall rule accepts all the inputs from source 10.1.10.240 with port 1122 to destination 10.1.10.60 with port 1443 where the protocol is tcp.

  • The firewall rules will be executed sequentially.

Assigning a firewall template to DNS Appliance

  • Go to Network Management -> DNS Appliances -> Select a DNS Appliance to which the firewall template is to be applied -> Click on Edit -> Select a firewall template from the drop down -> Click on OK

  • The rules in the firewall template will be applied to the DNS Appliance.

Modifying a firewall template

  • Go to Network Management -> DNS Threat Management -> Select a firewall template and click Edit.

  • User can modify an existing firewall rule or add a new firewall rule.

  • In order to modify a firewall rule, user should select the rule and make appropriate changes, then click Update Rule.

  • The order of the firewall rules can be changed by clicking on MoveRuleUp and MoveRuleDown.

  • After making the necessary changes, click OK.

Deleting a Firewall template

  • Go to Network Management -> DNS Threat Management -> Select a firewall template and click Delete button -> Select a rule to delete -> Click on Delete Rule -> Click OK

DNS RPZ
Overview

The DNS RPZ feature allows the network operator to control the behavior of responses to DNS queries. Using this feature, the known “bad guys” can be prevented from causing malicious damage by eliminating them at their source, DNS system.

Adding RPZ Template

  • To create a new RPZ template, click Network Management -> DNS Threat Management -> RPZ Templates -> Click on Add and enter the Name, Description, Zone name, Policy File and Certificate file -> Click on Ok.

  • User can provide the External Feed from third parties in the Add RPZ Template screen.

  • The RPZ policy files are created to control the behavior of responses to DNS queries and mention the name of the policy file in Policy file field.

  • Upload the Certificate file and click OK to create RPZ template.

  • Apply the RPZ template to DNS Appliance in Edit DNS Appliance screen and click OK.

  • The policies defined in the RPZ policy file will be applied to the DNS Appliance.

  • User can assign multiple RPZ templates to DNS Appliances by selecting multiple RPZ templates in Edit DNS Appliance screen.

Modifying RPZ Template

  • To modify an existing RPZ template, click Network Management -> DNS Threat Management -> RPZ Templates -> Select an RPZ template and click Edit.

  • Make the necessary changes and click Ok. The changes made to RPZ templates also apply to the DNS Appliances if the RPZ template is associated with DNS Appliance.

Deleting RPZ Template

  • To delete an RPZ template, click Network Management -> DNS Threat Management -> RPZ Templates -> Select an RPZ template and click Delete.

  • If the RPZ template is associated with any DNS Appliance, it will give an error message while deleting the RPZ template. The user should remove the references from the DNS Appliance and then delete the RPZ template.

Adding RPZ Policy File

  • To create RPZ policy file, click Network Management -> DNS Threat Management -> RPZ Policy Files. Click on Add and enter the policy file name, add the RPZ policy files. Add new RPZ policy Rule dialog box contains the following fields:



S. No

Field Name

Description

Policy Trigger

Enter the valid policy trigger.

Policy RR Type

Select the RR type from the dropdown.

Policy RH Value

Enter the Policy RH Value.



  • After entering the following details, click Ok to save the changes. User can edit/ delete the policy files accordingly from this page.

  • After adding the RPZ Policy files, click OK to create the RPZ policy rule file.

Modifying RPZ Policy File

  • To modify the RPZ policy file, user must select the Policy file to be modified and click Edit. This will prompt the user to a confirmation message “Are you sure you want to update the selected policy file?” Click on Ok to update the policy file.

Deleting RPZ Policy File

  • To delete RPZ policy file, select the file to be deleted and click Delete. If the RPZ policy file is used by any RPZ template, then the user will not be able to delete the policy file.

Download RPZ Policy Files

  • TCPWave IPAM provides the user with a feature to download the RPZ policy files. Select the RPZ policy file to be downloaded and click Download. The file will be downloaded successfully.

Upload RPZ Files

  • TCPWave IPAM allows the user to upload the policy file to IPAM. Click on Upload and enter the Policy File Name, select the Local Policy File and click validate. The file will be validated and uploaded successfully.

Deleting OFAC Countries

Select a single OFAC country and click Delete button. This asks the user for Delete confirmation “Are you sure that you want to delete the selected record?” Click on YES and the record will be successfully deleted from the grid.

User can select multiple entries and click Delete button. This action deletes all the selected records at a time.

Export Data

User can export the grid data to PDF, Excel, CSV with the help of the export buttons provided on the grid.

DNS Tunnel Detection

DNS Tunneling is a method of cyber-attack that encodes the data of other programs or protocols in DNS queries and responses. Recursive DNS resolvers (Cache servers) can be used to transmit intellectual property using encoded DNS queries. (Corporate espionage). Malware can multiply itself where the Command and Control (C&C) servers make the malware on a client more and more potent.

Network security is compromised by DNS tunnels. Captive portals can be evaded using DNS tunnels.


DNS tunnel detection uses supervised machine learning algorithm called random forest classifier to classify the queries into two groups: whitelisted and malicious. The classifier is pretrained with the data obtained from different tunneling clients such as Iodine, Ozyman etc. Live tcpdump on port 53 will be used as input data to the detection thread which runs every 6 minutes. The predicted output of the machine learning model will go through rules engine to confirm the attack. DNS Tunnel Detection detects, controls and analyzes tunneling traffic with following options in the UI.

  • Suspicious Domains Information:

This grid shows the suspicious domains that are detected by DNS Tunnel Detection process.

User can select one or more domains and whitelist the domains using Whitelist button. User will not see alerts for the whitelisted domains. If the domains whitelisted are blocked previously, these domains will be removed from firewall rules. User needs to perform full sync of the recursion enabled DNS appliances after whitelisting the domains.

User can select one or more domains and block the domains using Block button. These domains will be added to the firewall rules. User needs to perform full sync of the recursion enabled DNS appliances after blocking the domains.

User can select one or more domains and delete the domains from the TIMS database. Delete action doesn't update or delete any firewall rules.

User can import the domains using Import Domain Reputation Data button. Import accepts CSV file with columns Domain and Whitelisted. Domain column accepts the domain name. Whitelisted column accepts false or true. Domain with Whitelisted column value as false will be blocked whereas domain with Whitelisted column value will be whitelisted from firewall rules.

  • Retrain Model:

Use Retrain Model button to retrain the machine learning model with whitelisted reputation data. The CSV should have a column with header dns.qry.name and with queries such as www.tcpwave.com as the values. For better performance of the model, it is recommended to use 4000 to 5000 unique queries without PTR queries to retrain the model.

  • DNS Tunnel Detection Rules:

The live queries after going through ML model, go through one more filtering rules engine. Weightage is given to each suspicious query based on the DNS Tunnel Detection Rules. The threshold counts are to be taken for a 5min interval of time.

Query Count Threshold Per Domain defines the number of queries per domain. Weightage will be given to the query as suspicious whose domain exceeds this number.

Query Count Threshold Per Host defines the number of queries per host. Weightage will be given to the query as suspicious whose domain exceeds this number.

Full Query Length Threshold defines the query length. Weightage will be given to the query as suspicious whose length exceeds this number.

Maximum Sub Query Length Threshold defines the maximum sub query length. Weightage will be given to the query as suspicious whose maximum sub query length exceeds this number.

Maximum Integer Percentage Threshold Out of All Sub Queries defines the maximum integer percentage out of all the sub queries. Weightage will be given to the query as suspicious whose maximum integer percentage of all the sub queries exceeds this number.

  • DNS Traffic Analysis:

Select the DNS Remote Appliance dropdown and click submit to see the DNS traffic analysis charts of the DNS traffic analyzed in the latest execution of the detection thread. The dropdown populates the appliances where DNS Tunnel Detection is enabled.

  • Download Suspicious Queries:

Use this button to download the suspicious queries detected in the latest execution of the detection thread.

The path for DNS Tunneling: Infrastructure Management >> Performance Management >> DNS Statistics >> DNS Tunnel Detection

DNS Templates

TCPWave IPAM provides default templates for various configuration settings for DNS Appliances and zone management. Apart from the default IPAM templates, users can create custom templates and use them to configure and deploy the IPAM entities.

Templates are also used to help enforce consistency and standards. Deploying from templates, helps to enforce corporate standards and security policies.

Templates are flexible, powerful, and easy to create. With some careful planning, templates can save time and effort, enforce corporate standards and play an important role in maintaining security.

DNS Appliance Template

The DNS Appliance profile can be managed via a DNS Appliance template. A DNS Appliance template allows for all the DNS Appliance profile options to be configured in the same way as in the DNS Appliance profile screen and for zones to be assigned to the template. DNS forwarders tab is enabled for appliance types BIND Auth, BIND Cache, Unbound in DNS appliance template screen. User can associate the DNS forwarders to these appliance templates and assign them to BIND Auth, BIND Cache, Unbound and BIND Auth+Cache appliances from the DNS Appliance screen. Please refer to section “DNS Forwarders” under “DNS Zones” category for more details.

Enable DNSTAP Logs

Optional

This checkbox is enabled for appliance types – BIND AUTH and BIND CACHE. When this appliance template is applied to DNS appliance, the following lines are added into the named.conf global options section

dnstap {all;};

dnstap-output file "/var/named/log/dnstap.log";

These logs are stored in the above-mentioned location. These files are restricted to 10MB. Transfers-out (Only on Master)

No

It is the maximum number of concurrent zone transfers outbound that will be permitted. The default value is 10. If this value is too large on a master server with many zones that are frequently updated, server will be too busy handling zone transfers to handle queries effectively. It will also need to be able to handle the volume of concurrent TCP client connections for zone transfers. Accepts a value between 1 and 30. This option is enabled for appliance type BIND AUTH.

Syntax:

transfers-out number;

Transfers-per-ns (Only on Slave)

No

It is a per-server limit on concurrent zone transfers inbound. The default value is 2. It's a preferred configuration setting, so that even though the overall maximum number of inbound zone transfers is larger, named is preventing itself from hitting any one master server too hard. If the per-server transfer rate is too high for the master servers, the attempted zone transfers are rejected, and the master server is added to the unreachable masters list (for up to 10 minutes). Accepts a value between 1 and 30. This option is enabled for appliance type BIND AUTH.

Syntax:

transfers-per-ns number;

Transfers-in (Only on Slave)

No

It is the maximum number of concurrent zone transfers inbound that will be permitted. The default value is 10. If this value is too large on a slave server with many zones that are frequently updated, server will be too busy handling zone transfers to handle queries effectively. Accepts a values between 1 and 30. This option is enabled for appliance type BIND AUTH.

Syntax:

transfers-in number;

Version

No

Enter version of the option template.

Zone Statistics

No

Click the checkbox when you want to enable zone statistics for the option template.

Empty Zones Enable

No

Click the checkbox if you want to enable empty zones for the option template.

Custom Parameters

No

Enter custom parameter value for the option template.

Forward

(Applicable for BIND Authoritative and BIND Cache only)

Optional

Forward is only relevant in conjunction with a valid forwarders statement. If set to Only the server will only forward queries, if set to First (by default) it will send the queries to the forwarder first and if not answered, forward will attempt to answer the query.

Forwarders

(Applicable for BIND Authoritative and BIND Cache only)

Optional

It defines a list of IP address(es) to which queries will be forwarded. These are relevant when used with the related forward statements

DNS Cookies

DNS Cookie is an Extended DNS (EDNS) option which, when both the client and server support it, allows the client to detect and ignore off-path spoofed responses, and the server to determine that a client's address is not spoofed.

Using cookies allows the client to do less work when sending queries, such as having to manage multiple sockets to get source port randomization, to prevent spoofed responses being received. DNS Cookie also allows a server to pick out legitimate repeat clients from a sea of spoofed-source queries, so long as the client supports the DNS Cookie option.

When the user tries to create a DNS option template for appliance types - BIND AUTH and BIND Cache, enable DNS cookie checkbox is displayed. If this checkbox is enabled, a new option cookie-secret is created in the options section in named.conf file of the remote. If this checkbox is disabled, the named.conf file doesn’t contain cookie-secret option.

  • rrset-order defines the order in which multiple records of the same type are returned. This works for any record type in which the records are similar not just A or AAAA RRs and covers the results in the ANSWER SECTION and the ADDITIONAL SECTION. The default is cyclic (round-robin).

  • The full specification of rrset-order is shown below. An ‘order_spec’ is defined as:

  • class class_name] [ type type_name] [ name “domain_name”] order ordering;

Non-Managed DNS Appliance Support

TCPWave IPAM supports DNS updates from TCPWave managed master appliances to Non-Managed DNS slave appliances. This can be done by creating an ACL with the desired external remote IP addresses and these addresses should not be used as TCPWave managed DNS appliances or domain controllers. Please refer to section DNS Access Control Lists for more information on creating an ACL. This ACL can be selected from the drop down (Custom Allow Transfer) provided on Zone Template details page. This will update the zone section in the named.conf of masters adding external remote appliances IP addresses to the zones for which this zone template has been associated. Now, the TCPWave managed DNS appliances start sending DNS updates to the Non-Managed DNS slave appliances. For receiving these updates, TCPWave managed DNS master appliances addresses must be added in the respective configuration files on the Non-Managed DNS slave appliance. The appliances communication key has to be added for the communication between the TCPWave managed DNS appliances and external appliances. User can get the appliance communication key in Zone template page by clicking on External Communication Key button. After adding above mentioned sections, restart the DNS services on the Non-Managed DNS slave appliances after which they start receiving DNS updates from masters.

Below are the sample modifications required to be done on the Non-Managed DNS slave appliance using BIND service.

#-------------------------

# Server Definition

#-------------------------

key “COMMUNICATION-KEY” {

algorithm HMAC-SHA512;

secret 1HVF90bx+6ywx5Ovr1SOCcL2inTDc0gYRoG6BK/TU+g8tAr3j0ptJsZ6OjfNxEYcMGDRt5m5z/it1gPe7+jJqA==”;

};

server <IP address of master appliance> {

keys “COMMUNICATION-KEY”;

provide-ixfr yes;

request-ixfr yes;

transfers 30;

transfer-format one-answer;

};


#-------------------------

# Zone Section

#-------------------------

zone “example.com” IN {

type slave;

file “/var/named/zones/slaves/db example.com”;

allow-notify {<IP address of master appliance>;};

masters {

<IP address of master appliance>;

};

check-names ignore;

zone-statistics yes;

};



In the server definition section, mention information of communication key and TCPWave managed DNS appliances from which updates are sent. In the above example, example.com is the zone assigned to the zone template.



DNS64 Configuration from IPAM

Overview

DNS64 is a mechanism for synthesizing AAAA resource records (RRs) from A RRs. A synthetic AAAA RR created by the DNS64 from an original A RR contains the same owner name of the original A RR but it contains an Ipv6 address instead of an IPv4 address. The Ipv6 address is an Ipv6 representation of the IPv4 address contained in the original A RR. The IPv6 representation of the IPv4 address is algorithmically generated from the IPv4 address returned in the A RR and a set of parameters configured in the DNS64 (typically, an IPv6 prefix used by IPv6 representations of IPv4 addresses and optionally other parameters).

Together with an IPv6/IPv4 translator, these two mechanisms allow an IPv6-only client to initiate communications to an IPv4-only Appliance using the FQDN of the Appliance.

DNS64 Prefixes

User can configure DNS64 prefixes from the DNS64 Menu located on the DNS Management page. Click on Network Management menu -> DNS Management -> DNS64 to create DNS64 prefix in TCPWave IPAM.

Adding DNS64 Prefix

User can define DNS64 prefixes by clicking Network Management menu -> DNS Management -> DNS64. The administrator can add/edit/delete any DNS64 Prefixes based on organization in which it is defined.

Field

Value

Name

DNS64 Prefix name to be defined in TCPWave IPAM

Prefix

DNS64 Prefix that instructs named to return mapped IPv4 addresses to AAAA queries

Suffix

DNS64 Suffix value defines to set the bits trailing the mapped IPv4 address bits. By default, these bits are set to ::.

Recursive Only

Yes/No

Break DNSSEC

Yes/No

Description

DNS64 Prefix Description

Clients

Clients ACL that determines which clients are affected by this directive. If not defined, it defaults to any;

Mapped

Mapped ACL that selects which IPv4 addresses are to be mapped in the corresponding A RRset. If not defined it defaults to any;

Exclude

The optional exclude ACL allows specification of a list of IPv6 addresses that will be ignored when they appear in a domain name’s AAAA records



Applying DNS64 Prefix

Created DNS64 prefixes can be applied to a DNS Appliance by clicking add/edit DNS Appliance from the DNS Management screen. Select available DNS64 prefixes and add to the DNS Appliance.

Below screen shows the synthesized AAAA resource records (RRs) which are returned from BIND for DNS Appliance TCPWave00001Remote.tcpwave.com.

DNS64 in BIND

In BIND, DNS64 can be configured with the following options in named.conf under option section

[ dns64 ipv6-prefix {

[ clients {address_match_list} ; ]

[ mapped {address_match_list } ; ]

[ exclude {address_match_list } ; ]

[ suffix ip6-address; ]

[ recursive-only yes_or_no; ]

[ break-dnssec yes_or_no; ]

} ; ]

[ dns64-Appliance name]

[ dns64-contact name]

DNS64

This directive instructs named to return mapped IPv4 addresses to AAAA queries when there are no AAAA records. It is intended to be used in conjunction with a NAT64. Each DNS64 defines one DNS64 prefix. Multiple DNS64 prefixes can be defined. Compatible IPv6 prefixes have lengths of 32, 40, 48, 56, 64 and 96 additionally, a reverse IP6.ARPA zone will be created for the prefix to provide a mapping from the IP6.ARPA names to the corresponding IN-ADDR.ARPA names using synthesized CNAMEs.

DNS64-Appliance and DNS64-contact

dns64-Appliance and dns64-contact can be used to specify the name of the Appliance and contact for the zones. These are settable at the view/options level. These are not settable on a per-prefix basis.

Each dns64 supports an optional clients ACL that determines which clients are affected by this directive. If not defined, it defaults to any. Each dns64 supports an optional mapped ACL that selects which IPv4 addresses are to be mapped in the corresponding A Rrset. If not defined it defaults to any.

Normally, DNS64 won’t apply to a domain name that owns one or more AAAA records, these records will simply be returned. The optional exclude ACL allows specification of a list of IPv6 addresses that will be ignored if they appear in a domain name’s AAAA records and DNS64 will be applied to any A record the domain name owns. If not defined, exclude defaults to :: ffff:0.0.0.0/96.

An optional suffix can also be defined to set the bits trailing the mapped IPv4 address bits. By default, these bits are set to ::. The bits matching the prefix and mapped IPv4 address must be zero.

Recursive-only

If recursive-only is set to yes, the DNS64 synthesis will only happen for recursive queries. The default is set to No.

break-dnssec

If break-dnssec is set to yes, then the DNS64 synthesis will happen even if the result, if validated, would cause a DNSSEC validation failure. If this option is set to no (the default), the DO is set on the incoming query, and there are RRSIGs on the applicable records, synthesis will not happen.

Eg: acl rfc1918 { 10/8; 192.168/16; 172.16/12; };

dns64 64:FF9B::/96 {

clients { any; };

mapped { !rfc1918; any; };

exclude { 64:FF9B::/96; ::ffff:0000:0000/96; };

suffix ::;

};
